Muntemurro, who led the Gunners to their first Women’s Super League title in seven years in 2019, said he wanted his decision to be made public so the club could “get the process going” of finding his successor The 51-year-old cited being away from his family behind his decision but added it “felt like the right time” to step away from football “in the context of where I am as a coach”  “It’s been a cycle of nine years in which I haven’t really stopped,” said Montemurro,  “You know what it’s like in the off season, you get your three, four weeks [off] but you don’t stop, you’re always thinking about recruiting staff, playing and going forward and it’s not really a break. Just to not think about football for a while is going to be really nice, [but] really strange.” Montemurro would not be drawn on whether he would play an active role in helping to find his successor, but stressed that “there’s enough good people” at Arsenal for such a process.  Who next for Arsenal? Interest in Arsenal’s managerial vacancy will be vast, but few coaches will have the credentials and experience to fit the bill for one of the biggest jobs in the sport. Whoever comes in will be tasked with not only continuing with the dynamic, passing style of football Montemurro has overseen, but most importantly with trying to reassert Britain’s most successful women’s team historically back at the summit of the English game and not allow Chelsea and Manchester City’s recent stranglehold to continue any longer. That will be hugely difficult. Former Wales manager Jayne Ludlow will be among the strongest contenders, not least because of her links with Arsenal, where she spent 13 years of her successful playing career.   The 42-year-old was an integral part of the Arsenal side that won a historic quadruple of trophies in 2007 and was among the legends of an era where the club enjoyed unprecedented dominance of the game. Ludlow left her role as Wales coach by mutual consent in January after seven years in charge. She has taken up a role with Fifa but is understood to be interested in the right club job. Winner of the  , Jill Ellis is arguably the highest-profile manager in the women’s game and the fact she also happens to be English will inevitably mean she is closely linked with any big jobs in the WSL. The 54-year-old from Portsmouth stepped down from her role with the US national team shortly after 2019’s world title and she was understood to be among the interviewed candidates for the England job in 2020, before Holland’s  . Given her almost unrivalled international success and her extensive honours list, Ellis can rightly command a large salary, and that might be a slight stumbling block for Arsenal. But many fans of the north London club will hope the club will at least be speaking to her. As one of only five different managers to have won the WSL, Matt Beard has the necessary experience to help Arsenal mount a serious title challenge again, having won the league twice with Liverpool in 2013 and 2014. He is currently providing maternity cover for Bristol City manager Tanya Oxtoby until the end of the season, but is set to be a free agent this summer, with his stock high after turning the West Country club’s form around. But would Arsenal's board consider the leap from the Robins to the north Londoners to be too great? If Arsenal were to look to a former manager, Laura Harvey is as good as they come and guided Arsenal to the 2011 and 2012 WSL titles. However, she is currently employed as the United States’ Under-20 coach and is reportedly happy on the other side of the pond. Arsenal are currently fourth in the WSL table and on a four-game winning run as they continue to target a Champions League spot for next season. Under his three and a half year tenure, Arsenal have reached four domestic cup finals, including back-to-back Continental League Cup wins, and a Champions League quarter-final. Montemurro said he was a “mess” when he told players of his decision after training on Wednesday, a moment he described as “teary”.  “It was extremely difficult because we’ve built some great friendships,” said Montemurro.  “They’ve all had an effect on me, every player, even ones that are not with me here and have moved on. “The biggest thing I was scared of was that they’d be upset and never let me back into the club, but I can sit here and safely say that I’m forever part of the Arsenal family and I was one of the lucky ones who got to work here.”

The chronology of a season can sometimes warp perception, and it should not be forgotten just how good Jack Grealish's performances  Grealish is entering his prime   in the first portion of the campaign. He appeared to gain a yard of pace and even accounting for a spell on the sidelines, his statistics speak for themselves.  Only Kevin De Bruyne has more expected assists per 90 minutes, only Bruno Fernandes has played more key passes while Harry Kane and Fernandes are the only players with more goal-creating actions than Grealish this Premier League season.  His form earned him England starts in the autumn, although his place in Gareth Southgate's XI at the European Championship is likely to be a keen subject of debate. With Manchester City and Manchester United admirers, it could be a crucial summer for Grealish on and off the pitch.   assesses his options:  Aston Villa are in a very strong position after tying down Grealish to a five-year contract last summer. Villa’s wealthy owners Nassef Sawiris and Wes Edens oversaw the fifth-highest net transfer spend in the Premier League last summer, in spite of the financial impact of the pandemic. They do not appear desperate to balance the books with a big sale.   Villa valued Grealish at £70m last year but that asking price has increased to more than £100m now. That figure corresponds nicely to the cost of relegation; essentially, Villa would want to be compensated for the increased risk of relegation the loss of Grealish would bring.  That is a more remote prospect than it was 12 months ago. Dean Smith's squad has greater depth of quality, with the addition of Ollie Watkins, Ross Barkley and Bertrand Traore diversifying their attacking threat, and Villa have spent the entirety of the season in the top half. Rather than worrying about relegation, Villa will now be determined to keep Grealish in order to challenge for Europe once again. Since Grealish's shin injury, Villa have won just one of their last six Premier League games.  Grealish's situation at Villa is frequently compared to Wilfried Zaha at Crystal Palace, but Villa look the more comfortable Premier League outfit despite this being their second season back. Losing Zaha would have almost rubber-stamped relegation for Palace, but Villa's position is not as perilous. Zaha appears to regret signing a long-term deal that has proved prohibitive to potential buyers, but Grealish is three years younger and so could be viewed as more worthy of a British record transfer fee.  This may be a sad reflection on English football considering we are talking about the fifth-most successful club in the country, but Aston Villa are not going to win the Premier League. There will forever be one fewer nought on the bookmakers' odds since Leicester City's 2016 fairytale but it is cosmically unlikely to be repeated. Villa will start each season as underdogs to finish in the Europa League places, never mind qualify for the Champions League.  They could be a danger in the cup competitions, reaching the Carabao Cup final in 2020, and perhaps that will suffice for Grealish. Villa have not won major silverware since the 1996 League Cup under Brian Little, and inspiring Villa to a trophy while wearing the captain's armband would certainly stir Grealish as a boyhood fan of the club. One trophy with Aston Villa could be worth 10 won elsewhere.  Staying at Villa could also be beneficial for Grealish as an individual: he is already considered one of the league's star players and everything at Villa Park is geared towards getting the best out of him. Just as Harry Kane could smash individual records and become a club legend (if he isn't already) by staying at Tottenham, Grealish might be driven by more personal motivations.  When it comes to assessing players and managers, it certainly feels as if football has moved on from the maxims of 'show us your medals' and 'it's a results business'. A more complex range of factors are now considered: issues of identity, belonging and whether the player or coach is the right 'fit' for a club. Grealish fits Villa, of that there can be no doubt. Matt Le Tissier was accused of a lack of ambition for not leaving Southampton, but one gets the sense today's football public would be more sympathetic.  The brutal truth though, is that if Grealish wants to satisfy the urge for a title he will need to go elsewhere. There are also financial incentives. Football is just like any other business: people move jobs to get paid. Players want to maximise the value of a short career and Grealish is no different.  United are one of the few clubs with the financial clout to buy Grealish. Paying a premium for the best British talent from within the Premier League fits the pattern of United's recruitment over the last few decades, especially now that players from the Sir Alex Ferguson-era are the club's key decision-makers.  Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's team lacked creativity and invention against deep-lying defences in his early days, though this has been alleviated since Bruno Fernandes' arrival. Grealish's dashing style, technical arrogance and willingness to take players on certainly marks him out as a potential 'United player' (a slightly woolly concept but we shall let that slide for now).  while Paul Pogba rediscovering his best form mean United are not quite as desperate for an attacking midfielder. Grealish has also played his best football for Aston Villa from the left, where United are quite well stocked: Marcus Rashford, Anthony Martial and Pogba all favour that side. Perhaps Grealish could enable Rashford to move through the middle but is that his optimal role? Furthermore, is Rashford the kind of striker Solskjaer wants to play with week-in, week-out?  United's principal problem in attack has been finding a player to occupy the right flank. Mason Greenwood has done well, but will naturally look to come inside and get shots off. United pursued Jadon Sancho and looked at Watford's Ismaïla Sarr because they wanted a player who could hold his width to balance off their right-footed forward on the left. This position, as well as striker, centre-back and central midfield, look a bigger priority than the areas Grealish likes to occupy.  City have the firepower to make significant acquisitions despite the pandemic. Grealish's quality in tight spaces makes it easy to imagine him in a Pep Guardiola team, against the low blocks Manchester City face every week. Guardiola loves attacking midfielders who can also dribble and unbalance opposition defences, once stating that it was Andres Iniesta who taught him the importance of having this type in the team. Direct comparisons are best avoided, but there are stylistic parallels between Grealish and Iniesta as right-footed dribblers who like to make out-to-in runs from the left.  In a squad like City's, Grealish would not necessarily replace a particular player in the starting XI but be one of several blue-chip attacking options. He could play on the left of the front three with Raheem Sterling switching back to the right. Or he could move inside as a left-sided No 8 in the position Ilkay Gundogan has occupied this season, with the German midfielder now past 30. Those are two of the most simple solutions - the possibilities are endless.  However,  , City's attention is squarely on Erling Haaland following the announcement that Sergio Aguero will depart at the end of the season. Despite their vast wealth, City are quite measured in the transfer market and buying two players of this stature in one window seems unlikely.  Liverpool's forward line is perhaps in need of a refresh, but they are one of the big clubs suffering the costs of the pandemic. Reports suggest and Liverpool under FSG are not associated with buying the biggest names on the market. Diogo Jota was signed last season and likes that inside left slot, and is closer to what Klopp wants in his wide forwards than Grealish: runs in behind and goals. Grealish is out of Tottenham and Arsenal's financial reach. Could Grealish move abroad? "If I’m Barcelona I’m buying him tomorrow morning it doesn’t matter how much it is," said former Arsenal and Villa player Paul Merson.  “I’m buying Jack Grealish because Jack Grealish at the Nou Camp would absolutely rip it up.” A nice idea, but Spain's biggest clubs are drowning in debt and in need of financial restructuring. For the first time in decades, Barcelona and Real Madrid might not be big players in the market.  Winning greater recognition at international level is sometimes a motivation for players moving to one of the bigger clubs, but that is not really the case for Grealish. Southgate is aware of his quality and has included him in recent squads.  Rather than a question of how much Grealish is rated, the tension with England appears to be a tactical one. Harry Kane is undroppable and,  , likes to roll off the forward line to link play (something he is very good at). Management is about finding balance however, and if your striker is doing this then he needs to be surrounded by players who make runs in behind. When Kane drags out centre-backs, there is green grass to exploit, something Heung-min Son does brilliantly alongside Kane for Spurs.  Fitness permitting, it seems Southgate wants to recreate this dynamic with Rashford from the left. It makes perfect sense, though it is harsh on Grealish. Playing Grealish alongside Kane in the same front three, with Mason Mount or Phil Foden in the team, risks making England too static and predictable with one too many players coming short to receive the ball to feet. Nevertheless, Grealish will surely be involved in some capacity.

As a Briton who can play tennis rather well,  , so it should be no surprise to find him eyeing up a career in golf in a manner so different to some of his colleagues. Ivan Lendl and Yevgeny Kafelnikov are two just grand slammers who thought they could hack it on the professional fairways when they zipped up their rackets. And they actually did go and hack up those perfectly manicured layouts in true hacker style when they dared tee it up in elite-golf competition.  Of the 15 invites Kafelnikov received for the European Tour and its feeder league, the Challenge Tour, he made exactly no cuts. Neither did Lendl.  . As we know, Murray, god bless him, is not an arrogant man and that is why he is peering several rungs down the food chain when it comes to his tennis afterlife in those pearly-gated country clubs.  “I really like golf and being a caddie on Tour would be exciting," he told Gentleman's Journal.  “To be up close and personal with top golfers and to learn about another sport like that. There’s probably also some crossover between tennis and golf on the mental side and things, and helping a golfer with that might be interesting.” It certainly might. In fact, it would be fascinating to see a knight of the realm carrying someone else’s clubs and being screamed at on the fourth fairway for having the wrong flavour protein bar in the bag.  How “up close and personal” does he fancy? Probably nose-to-nose if he thinks that as a 15-handicapper who shot 101 at Wentworth recently, can help out on the “mental side” of hitting a three iron 250 yards to that 18th green guarded by a lake. A forehand smash might just be the start of it. . On hearing about Murray’s impending application, The Tour Caddies, a group of some of the shrewdest operators out there, tweeted that it could be the ideal occupation for the 33-year-old, so long as he likes “a: dodgy Airbnbs, b: low job security and c: shouting at people to turn off their mobile phones.” Of course, the first two would not be a problem as Murray has the finances to travel in the same class of cabins and stay in the same hotels (although for his employer’s ego that could be an issue in itself). But acting as both a dogsbody and bodyguard for the pro could pose their own psychological challenges for a multi-millionaire. The lack of respect would surely get to him - and that does not necessarily come from the players, themselves. On the PGA Tour caddies are not generally allowed in the clubhouse, are certainly not permitted in the locker rooms and, on occasion, have disgracefully not been provided with adequate shelter for storms. The caddies refer to themselves as “rats” and the self-definition is only partly in jest. There are no contracts, no pay-offs, no sick pay. At the Masters they are instructed to wear those uncomfortable white jumpsuits and at regular events don garish bibs that are essentially advertising placards, with no cut of the bounty. The rewards? Those working for the top guys earn substantial sums, but the average looper struggles from week-to-week. And on the female tours it is worse. And how would Murray, a two-time gold medallist, being a caddie at the Olympics work?  Unlike coxes in the rowing races, caddies are not considered eligible for medals, but just like coxes they are required to undergo drugs testing if asked. In fairness, there will be other “competitors” in Tokyo being treated the same – the horses in the equestrian events. “But at least they'll get good wash down and a polo mint,” one caddie remarked. Murray would be appalled, but then, as a character who has regularly spoken up for women's rights, maybe he could emerge as the shop steward for this downtrodden section of humanity. The caddies could do with a champion of their cause.

The British and Irish Lions are considering holding a 10-day training camp in both Channel Islands of Jersey and Guernsey before departing for South Africa even though the  Warren Gatland, the Lions head coach had first explored the option of basing his squad in Jersey in case the tour had to be relocated to the UK and Ireland because of the global pandemic. revealed last Tuesday however that the Lions board had decided to proceed with the tour in South Africa after concluding the ‘home series’ option was not feasible for time, logistic and cost reasons. Gatland was so impressed with the facilities on the island however that the Lions are still considering using it for their pre-tour camp ahead of the game against Japan at Murrayfield on June 26. And it is understood that the head coach is now also exploring the option of spending several days training at Guernsey RFC in order to break up the 10-day camp that is set to assemble on June 14 for those players not involved in the Premiership semi-finals and final, which coincides with the game against Japan. Any players involved in the Pro 14 Rainbow Cup final on June 19 should be able to join up with the Lions in camp on the following day. The attraction of staging the camp on the Channel Islands is multi-layered. Jersey and Guernsey have the benefit of being both a neutral and a fresh venue - four years ago, the two-week training camp was staged at the national training bases of Wales and Ireland before the tour of New Zealand. Traditional 'bonding' sessions - key to successful Lions tours - are likely to be possible on the islands as the Covid protocols are much more relaxed because of the low rates of infection.  All restrictions are due to be lifted completely the same day that the camp is due to start. Given that the squad is likely to face biosecure bubble restrictions when they are in South Africa,  .   The state-of-the-art facilities at Strive, an elite performance complex currently under construction on land adjacent to the Jersey Reds clubs, includes an altitude chamber which will allow the players to prepare for the ‘thin air’ in Highveld in South Africa. The Lions squad will then travel to Edinburgh on June 24 for their final preparations for the game against Japan before  The decision has also been taken to scrap the traditional ‘farewell’ dinner, which is normally held on the night before departure. The dinner had become an overly corporate affair for sponsors and even before the pandemic restrictions was unlikely to be staged given the decision to travel to South Africa on the day after the Japan game. Meanwhile, the traditional ‘Messy Monday’ day when players first assemble to receive their kit and have medical checks and photo shoot is scheduled for a Wednesday for the first time (May 26) ahead of the final round of regular Premiership fixtures, which should avoid the friction of four years ago when it was held on the week that Saracens were preparing for their European Champions Cup final against Clermont Auvergne in Edinburgh.

South Africa have not played a Test match in over 500 days. Let that sink in. The decision to not participate in last year’s Rugby Championship has meant that the Springboks have not played together since brushing England aside in the Rugby World Cup final. Given how much thought and speculation goes into selecting everybody’s British and Irish Lions XV for the first Test, it only seems right to wonder how the Springboks will line up, having not played a Test match in close to 20 months. New head coach Jacques Nienaber has had no opportunity to work with most of his players, outside of last October’s ‘Springbok Showdown’ last year when a ‘Green’ side, coached by Nienaber’s predecessor Rassie Erasmus, took on Nienaber’s ‘Gold’ side back in October.  That fixture, however, only included players based in South Africa which, given the large number of frontline Springboks playing   in England, France and Japan, hardly gave Nienaber a full hand to work with. Also, the quality of the ‘Springbok Showdown’ was criticised on social media, given it essentially served as a pre-season outing ahead of the Currie Cup. Below, we look at the Springboks’ preparations, where the side from the World Cup final are now, some new faces who may break into the squad and predict the XV that will face the Lions in the first Test on July 24 in Johannesburg. Unconfirmed reports have suggested that South Africa will face the USA in a warm-up fixture ahead of facing the Lions, with USA head coach Gary Gold   that an offer had been made to play the Springboks before the Lions series. South Africa’s Super Rugby franchises are currently competing in pre-season ahead of the Guinness Pro14 Rainbow Cup, when the Bulls, Lions (SA), Sharks and Stormers will play against the current Pro14 sides, starting with derbies between the Bulls and Lions plus the Sharks against the Stormers on April 24. The final of the Rainbow Cup is scheduled for June 19, although depending on results the South African sides’ participation could be over by June 12.  That would give Nienaber and his coaching staff extra preparation time compared to the British and Irish Lions, with the Gallagher Premiership season not concluding until June 26, the same day the Lions face Japan at Murrayfield, and the tour then starting the following week on July 3 when the Lions face the Stormers in Cape Town.  - Left Wasps before the Rugby World Cup to sign for Toyota Verblitz in Japan, where he’s currently based.  - Still one of the best attackers in the game for Toulouse, with seven tries in the Top 14 this season.  - One of the breakout stars of the World Cup. Captained the Sharks to defeat in the Currie Cup final back in January.  - Signed for Munster after the World Cup and has made 18 appearances, overcoming a groin injury.  - Scored five tries for the Sharks in Super Rugby last year before the tournament was cancelled. Now in Japan with NTT Red Hurricanes.  - Joined Montpellier after the Rugby World Cup but ruptured his ACL last September, but he is on track to return in time for the Lions. - Still Sale’s talisman and his form has not dipped since the World Cup, making him a starter in the summer.  - Retired from Test rugby with the RWC final being  . Now in the US playing for Washington-based Old Glory DC.  - Good enough to play anywhere in the world but still in Cape Town with Western Province and the Stormers, for now. Has been linked with Harlequins.  - Signed a new contract to remain with the Stormers this week, turning down a deal in Japan, having been with the franchise now for a decade.   - Linked up with Toulon following the World Cup where he has been an important senior player in a rebuilding job.  - Had a disjointed start to life at Sale, with the 6ft 9in lock battling a shoulder injury, but he’s now building up steam under Alex Sanderson.  - The Springbok captain has swapped the Stormers for the Sharks in South Africa, a big move, and became the first rugby player to sign with agency Roc Nation   - The 2019 World Rugby men’s player of the year   at the start of 2020 and is now close to a return. Was linked with Munster but set to head to Japan.  - Returned from playing in Japan to join Jake White’s revolution at the Bulls, captaining the side to winning the Currie Cup back in January.   - Has spent the last two years in Japan, first with NTT Com Shining Arcs and now at Kubota Spears. Still yet to enter the prime of his career at 26. - Based with the Stormers after a brief stint in France before the 2019 RWC, and now the premier loosehead with Mtawarira retired. - Has stuck with Saracens dropping down to the Championship, starting this season in their defeat at Cornish Pirates. Playing at that level might hurt his chances.  - Snapped up by Munster along with De Allende to add some bulk, but the lock has been out for several months since damaging his ACL.  - Left Gloucester in June last year with the season on hold and has now taken up a contract in Japan with Honda Heat.  - Now retired after an excellent career with the Springboks and also with Bath,   - South Africa’s bolter in 2019 will be in the mix again for selection, continuing to play well for the Stormers.  - The veteran is now back in South Africa after leaving Montpellier, heading home to the Free State to play for the Cheetahs at 33. You wouldn’t rule him out.  - Retired and turns 40 in May, with the former Saracen having previously come out of retirement to be part of the World Cup squad in Japan two years ago.  - Was playing for Toulouse as a World Cup joker before getting the call to head to Japan to replace the injured Trevor Nyakane. Now back in South Africa with the Sharks.  - Unlucky to pick up an injury in South Africa’s opening game against New Zealand. Another Currie Cup winner with the Bulls in January.  - Excellent on the Sevens circuit for many years before switching to XVs to make the World Cup squad. Now in Japan with Yamaha Jubilo.  - A fan favourite at Northampton Saints before departing last summer to join Montpellier in France, where the Top 14 side have only won seven league matches this season.  - Still running the show for the Lions and has captained the side recently in pre-season ahead of the new season. - Recently re-signed to stay in the Western Cape, the much-hyped fly-half/full-back is still yet to fulfil his potential.  - Another player to unfortunately pick up an injury in that opening game against New Zealand, when he came off the bench. Now in Japan with Canon Eagles.  - Hugely exciting talent on the wing who has combined well with Lukhanyo Am for the Sharks recently and will be in the mix. - Recovering from a long-term injury having recently moved south to the Stormers from the Bulls, where he’s a frontrunner for the full-back slot. As you can see from the above, only three of the squad from 2019 have since retired from Tests - Mtawarira, Louw and Brits - with a couple of older players in Vermeulen and Steyn still around and playing well enough to be considered to face the Lions. However, there are a number of players who have put their hands up too, either in South Africa during last year’s Super Rugby and Currie Cup campaigns or based overseas. Possibly the strongest pick of the lot from this list. Fassi was a lot of fun to watch for the Sharks in Super Rugby last year and a regular during his side’s run to the Currie Cup final, despite suffering a shoulder injury that kept him out for three months last year.  Fassi’s taller than Le Roux and has electric pace, and while you can understand if Jacques Nienaber sticks with the more experienced option of Le Roux, Fassi would be a box-office addition to South Africa’s backline. Simelane, a standout a Under-20 level, won Backline Player of the Year, as voted by South Africa’s professional rugby players at the end of 2020 after an excellent spell for the Lions. In a similar position to Fassi, in that Simelane might be a talent for a few years down the road given there are experienced options ahead of him in Am, De Allende and Kriel. But it would be good to see Simelane in the mix. Dweba earned a move to France after some remarkable form for Cheetahs, winning Currie Cup Player of the Year in 2019 and scoring seven tries in the Pro14 before the season was cancelled. He was also named by Rugbyrama as one of the top 10 summer signings in France back in January. On that form, he at least deserves a chance. Van der Merwe has been capped by the Springboks before, back in 2018, but has looked excellent for Sale this season, incredibly physical with his ball-carrying. Plus, a call-up would increase the possibility of him playing against his brother, Scotland wing Duhan, who impressed in the Six Nations. Unfortunate to miss out on selection for the World Cup after the late surge made by Herschel Jantjies, but Papier has continued to play well for the Bulls, including in their recent Currie Cup triumph. Could be chosen as a third scrum-half ahead of Reinach. As has too often been the case in his career, injury might hinder Coetzee’s chances of being involved against the Lions, with the Ulster flanker set to return to South Africa soon after many years in Belfast where he has put together some excellent performances. A brilliant ball-carrier and threat over the breakdown.  and There’s real competition for the back-up loosehead shirt behind Steven Kitshoff, and Gqoboka and Nché faced off against each other recently in the Currie Cup final. Nché has impressed in the loose, showing good speed and hands, while Gqoboka wasn’t far away from making the World Cup squad. It’s a tight call, hence including both of them here. Incredibly athletic back-row forward, previously with the Stormers, who was one of the standouts in Super Rugby 2020 before the tournament was cancelled. About to combine with Kolisi again, this time in Durban, and deserves another look after six caps in 2018. The lack of preparation time, and the fact that only two players from the matchday 23 who won in Yokohama have retired, suggests that Nienaber will attempt to pick a similar XV to the World Cup final. The options of a six-two and five-three bench split have both been included among the replacements, given South Africa’s preference for the former during the World Cup. Kitshoff replacing Mtawarira as the starting loosehead is fairly automatic, and while Fassi will push Le Roux hard, you expect Nienaber to stick with experience. On the bench, someone needs to fill the 17 shirt and Nché could edge out Gqoboka, while Coetzee, almost out of sentiment and hoping he recovers from injury in time to be part of this series, would be the replacement back-row ahead of Notshe or potentially Kwagga Smith. A six-two split would also mean opting for a fly-half option in the 23 shirt, meaning Francois Steyn getting in ahead of Jesse Kriel. The concerns for Nienaber have to be the fitness of Pollard and Du Toit, both vital players for this side, although it seems the worst is over for Du Toit, now back in training having recovered from that concerning thigh injury, meaning he should return to the field soon. Pollard, meanwhile, is still on the mend and while the signs are positive, should he not be ready in time that would open the door for Elton Jantjies. Or, and whisper his name in fear if you’re still scarred from 2009, a resurgent Morné Steyn, who has just won another Currie Cup with the Bulls at 36. Wouldn’t that be something.

Who runs English cricket? The Rajasthan Royals or the England & Wales Cricket Board? The answer is the ECB of course but the Royals are becoming an ever more influential presence with contacts at the very top level of decision making in English cricket. We are not just talking about the cream of England talent on their payroll: Jos Buttler, Ben Stokes and Jofra Archer. But their influence stretches deeper, all the way to the ECB’s executive board. On Nov 2 last year the ECB announced that Ron Kalifa had joined its board as an independent non-executive director. He was already a member of the Hundred board and the ECB’s audit and risk committee. Kalifa is a successful businessman who is a director of the Bank of England, a non-executive director for Transport for London and previously led Worldpay, a technology payments company. Clearly a man of talent the ECB needs as it negotiates the pandemic and the changing world of digital revenue streams. On Jan 15 this year, two months after Kalifa was appointed an ECB non-executive director,  the Rajasthan Royals announced its lead investor, Emerging Media, had increased its shareholding in the franchise to over 50 percent through new equity fundraising worth a reported £25m. Its press release announced Kalifa as one of a “number of new individual investors”.  Manoj Badale, the owner of Emerging Media and Royals co-founder, said: “Investors are now recognising the value of sports franchises. EMIPL’s increased ownership of the franchise and expanded network of US-based, value-add investors presents an exciting opportunity to drive the growth of both the Rajasthan Royals and the IPL.” The IPL and English cricket has never been closer. The launch of the Hundred this year is the ECB’s attempt to copy the success of the IPL. Last week  revealed the board is considering   hoping it will lead Indian players to play in the competition, boosting its value overseas considerably.  This week the IPL versus England debate deepened when Ashley Giles, the England team director, said he worried   and the ECB and sign IPL deals instead if they curbed their participation in the tournament. This summer we could see Stokes, Buttler and Archer (fitness permitting) playing in the IPL final rather than a Test match at Lord’s, the first time England fans will have seen the team in action in the flesh for more than 12 months.  An ECB spokesman denied there is a conflict of interest: "Ron was appointed to the ECB Board after a rigorous selection process. His interest in the Rajasthan Royals was fully declared and he is not involved in Board discussions if there is any conflict. We are comfortable that this does not present any issues with his position on the Board." Last week the ECB announced that Delia Bushell was not going to seek a second term as a non-executive director of the ECB. A press release said she was now “engaged in advisory and investment work for the sport and media sectors, so has decided not to seek a second term on the ECB Board given the conflicts that might arise with her new role.” The board clearly takes conflicts of interest seriously.  The Royals-ECB link does not end at Kalifa. Sir Andrew Strauss is chairman of the ECB’s cricket committee, an influential role that has power over how the professional game is played in England. He also attends ECB board meetings in a non-voting capacity, invited by Ian Watmore when he took over as chairman in September last year. Strauss is a consultant for the Rajasthan Royals, advising on cricket matters similar to his role with the ECB. Since leaving his job as England’s director of cricket in 2018, Strauss has become a freelance cricket consultant. He is entitled to work for wherever he can.  Rajasthan have made no secret of their links with England, and have positioned themselves as the most English of the IPL franchises.  The Royals appointed a new chief executive in September, Mike Fordham. Fordham is a former employee of the ECB. He was instrumental in setting up the Hundred competition with Tom Harrison, who recruited him from IMG where they used to be colleagues, and where Fordham helped establish the IPL. Fordham left the ECB in 2019. Before joining Rajasthan, Fordham worked briefly as a consultant for Oakwell Sports Advisory group, specialists at linking corporate finance with sport. Fordham was one of the the authors of a report released by Oakwell last April, at the height of the pandemic when English cricket was fearing a blank summer and losses of more than £300m, that recommended the ECB sell equity in Hundred teams to private financiers in India, where there is no shortage of rich businessmen looking to buy into cricket. Not many have better inside knowledge of English cricket and the Hundred than Fordham. His report concluded selling equity in the Hundred would help alleviate covid losses and increase interest in India. “The Hundred needs to be able to attract Indian players and subsequently an Indian fanbase too,” it said. “The Indian subcontinent constitutes 90% of the 1 billion cricket fans aged 16-69 globally. Indian investment into the Hundred, including from IPL team owners may facilitate the involvement of Indian players in the longer term. In addition to generating revenue out of India, this would be vital in unlocking the South Asian UK-based fanbase.”  and a sensible move given it would take some of the soaring cost base off the ECB and bring new money, new ideas to a tournament that has no history and is essentially a blank piece of paper.  Badale told   last year: “We would naturally have a look, as we do at opportunities all over the world, and particularly given our huge fan following in the UK.” Kumar Sangakkara was appointed Royals’ director of cricket in January. Sangakkara is also president of the MCC. Cricket is a small world, and connections are everywhere so it is no surprise that an IPL franchise with a British founder has established links within English cricket. But it is a big change from a decade ago. Then the Royals linked up with Hampshire as they dreamt of creating the world’s first franchise across continents. However the ECB, spooked by the move, were very hostile at that point. Hampshire and the Royals was an experiment that did not last. Now the Royals influence is more subtle.  Why does this matter? There is no suggestion anyone is working against the interests of English cricket and all are incredibly experienced, knowledgeable figures the sport benefits from having on board. But it’s important to realise the IPL’s tentacles are not just limited to the cricket field and player appearances. It’s creeping into more and more aspects of English cricket.

Talks have begun to allow England to name a squad larger than 23 players for the European Championship,   can reveal. Uefa’s executive committee was told on Wednesday that relaxing squad limits would be considered when it came to drafting the tournament regulations in a bid to stop it being wrecked by coronavirus. That could either mean teams  or designated players being kept on standby in the event of a Covid-19 outbreak. As revealed by  , England players and staff could also be banned from mixing with family and friends while involved in the Euros to avoid spreading the virus amid doubts they will be fully vaccinated in time. Both measures will be considered to stop the forfeiting of matches at the tournament, something that could see a country eliminated without kicking a ball. Relaxing normal squad limits would mirror the action taken by Uefa to prevent its other competitions being thrown into chaos, with teams able to call on additional players in the event of a spate of Covid-19 cases. With no real scope for rearranging matches at the Euros, it would be unthinkable for such a decision not to be made unless all squads were vaccinated beforehand given the dire consequences of games not taking place. The same could apply when it comes to deciding whether to ban players and staff from mixing with family and friends, a measure that has been imposed on England’s cricketers while they are on international duty. As revealed   the current timetable for the vaccine rollout in the UK means players based here may not receive their first doses until May at the earliest and may not get a second before the Euros finish. Normally, countries are limited to a squad of 23 players. They are unable to call up replacements in the event of injury or illness. Because of the coronavirus crisis. A major outbreak of Covid-19 in a squad could mean countries simply do not have enough players allowed to play a match. With no real scope for rearranging fixtures at the Euros, that country would otherwise be forced to forfeit the game. That could see them eliminated without kicking a ball and lead to millions being paid in compensation to broadcasters and other impacted parties. Countries will either be allowed to select larger squads than 23 or submit a list of designated standby players they could call upon only in the event of an outbreak of the virus. Uefa has already relaxed squad limits in its club competitions and the current Under-21 Championship finals, at which teams are able to call upon players outside of squad lists submitted before those competitions began. Regulations for these state matches will go ahead as long as a team has 13 eligible players available including at least one goalkeeper.

Jofra Archer underwent successful surgery to his right hand on Monday, with a fragment of glass removed from the middle finger of his right hand, according to an ECB statement. Having a piece of glass in his bowling hand, since an accident  , goes a long way to explaining why Archer was not at his best this winter. He led the T20 attack in India and had only one bad game, the last, when England went down 3-2. But, having been rested for the Test series in Sri Lanka, Archer did not really strike in the Test series in India - not that any pace bowler did. In two Tests he took four wickets, and had to miss the last Test with another injury to his right elbow, which has been troubling him on and off for more than a year. "Archer will now commence two weeks of rehabilitation," the ECB added. "Further update on his elbow injury will be provided once he has returned to bowling to assess the effectiveness of his recent injection." Only when Archer has returned to bowling will the ECB decide on  . Either way, another winter has passed  - or even another year. James Anderson and Stuart Broad were given the new ball last summer ahead of England’s fastest bowler, and as often as not Chris Woakes would also bowl ahead of Archer, so that he was reduced to fourth seamer in the pecking order. Archer took 22 wickets in his four Tests, at only 20 runs each in the white heat of an Ashes series in 2019. Dukes ball, yes, in England, yes, but it was still the most impressive of debuts. Stuart Broad would take the first over and nip out David Warner, then Archer would take the new ball at the other end, work up through the gears in his old-fashioned style, and scare the wits out of Australia’s batsmen, who had seen nothing like it from an England bowler in their living memory except Andrew Flintoff in 2005. Archer, subsequently, in nine Tests, has taken 20 wickets at 42.9 each. Sometimes he has started a spell in third gear, and stayed in third gear, so his strike-rate has been one Test wicket every 14 overs. His batting too has gone backwards. He was averaging 31 for Sussex when he was picked for England. He could bat properly, at eight or nine. Darren Gough was the same, a bowling all-rounder when he made his England debut, before sliding down the order to No 11 and batting like one. A terrific waste in both cases. There are two sources of encouragement though. One is that the England selectors and management have been finally strong enough to insist that Anderson and Broad should no longer play together, except in exceptional circumstances,  . Archer this summer may be allowed the new ball again. Secondly, Jon Lewis was appointed England’s pace bowling coach last month on a full-time basis. Archer turns 26 on Thursday, and if anyone is going to get the best out of him it is the man who coached Archer when he was blossoming at Sussex. While a tough and uncompromising heavy-duty seamer himself in county cricket with one Test for England, Lewis belongs to the kind and considerate school of coaching, and was also Archer's landlord in Brighton. Lewis has allowed Archer to warm up in his own way like former fast bowlers used to do, by merely turning his arm over before the start then easing into his work and building up pace during a spell. This did not go down well with the management when England first went on tour with Archer to New Zealand, but Lewis knows his man.

Following  , it did not take long for focus to shift to Lions selection. Gregor Townsend backed his players to the hilt once again, indicating that as many as or eight or nine Scotland players should be included in Warren Gatland’s squad, particularly   and in the Stade de France. In both 2013 and 2017, just three Scots were in the initial touring party. This number is almost certain to increase, but the question remains how many Scotland players should tour? It is easy to recognise the quality of this Scotland side, but earning selection over players from three other nations requires more than just being a good international player. In certain positions it requires being genuinely exceptional.   assesses which Scotland players should go on the Lions tour on a case-by-case basis. For the purpose of this article, it is assumed that both   and   are automatic selections whose merits do not need to be debated. Neither Stuart McInally nor Fraser Brown have been considered due to their lack of Six Nations game time, although both would have been in contention if it were not for their untimely injuries.  Sutherland has had a meteoric rise since earning a recall to the Scotland setup in 2020. Since then he has established himself as the starting loosehead, delivering a number of impressive performances in the loose and at scrum time. The Edinburgh prop is a powerful carrier and throughout the Six Nations only conceded one scrum penalty in just under 300 minutes of action.  However, there is plenty of competition in his position. After a phenomenal Six Nations, Wyn Jones looks a shoo-in to make the squad. England have a number of talented looseheads in Mako Vunipola, Ellis Genge and Joe Marler - who should not be discounted despite missing the Six Nations. Cian Healy and Dave Kilcoyne are both solid international performers too. Despite not having a huge amount of international experience, Sutherland is in a strong position to make the squad. Against South Africa, as England found out in the World Cup final, strong scrummaging is a must - and Sutherland can provide that. This could give him the edge over Vunipola who has looked vulnerable at the set-piece. Fagerson was in prime position to join Tadhg Furlong and Kyle Sinckler as the third tighthead in the squad before the Six Nations. The Glasgow prop has played a lot of international rugby for someone his age and, after initially flourishing in the loose, Fagerson had shored up his scrummaging. The 25 year-old carries well and is strong in defence - Fagerson did not miss a single tackle during the Six Nations. However, the red card he received against Wales could count against him. Although the sending off was controversial in the eyes of some, the lapse was  and there is no margin for error in the current climate.  Fagerson and Tomas Francis, a Gatland favourite, are likely to be in a straight shootout for the third tighthead spot - although Andrew Porter could also come into the reckoning. Francis played a lot of international rugby under the former Wales coach which could edge it for the Exeter man. The Lions once again have an abundance of talent in the second row to choose from. Maro Itoje, Alun Wyn Jones and James Ryan are all very likely to go if fit. Iain Henderson and Tadhg Beirne both had superb Six Nations campaigns while Courtney Lawes was picked by Gatland in 2017.  It is likely that Gatland will pick four out-and-out locks as well as a player that can cover both second and back row - with player of the tournament nominee Beirne primed for this role. Therefore, despite being a very good player who gets through an incredible amount of work - Gray had the most combined carries, tackles and ruck involvements of any forward in the tournament - he could well be struggling. Gray did not have his best game against Ireland when his Lions rivals stepped up to dominate the lineout which will not help his case. One cannot help but feel Gray will be a victim of talent in his position, just as Joe Launchbury was in 2017. Ritchie rarely fails to perform in a Scotland jersey, combining tenacious defence with impressive scavenging skills at the breakdown. He won four jackal turnovers during the Six Nations, a number only bettered by Henderson and Beirne.  The Edinburgh flanker is certainly in with a shout, but the back row is extremely competitive. Ritchie is a talent who has the attitude of a Gatland player. However, he might not be quite good enough to make the plane this time around when compared to the other options of Tom Curry, Sam Underhill, Justin Tipuric, Josh Navidi and compatriot Hamish Watson. To some, it may seem odd to even have Watson as a debate. But that is a reflection of the competition rather than the player. Curry, Underhill, Tipuric and Navidi are just four other flankers that also merit a tour place, although the injury that ruled Underhill out of the Six Nations could cost the Bath flanker a spot. The question for Watson is whether he can impose his unique game against the most physical side in world rugby. His performances throughout the Six Nations suggest the answer is yes. Watson completed all 60 tackles he attempted during the competition, proving his defence is just as strong as his signature Tasmanian Devil-esque running game. Price has had a mixed Six Nations. He has created moments of magic but also made basic errors at times.  Unlike the back row, scrum-half is a position of weakness for the Lions which could yet see Price sneak onto the plane. Concerns remain about his box-kicking, however, which could yet put off Gatland who will need his nine to execute a consistent kicking game. Price’s volume of international game-time over the past few years means he will undoubtedly be in the reckoning.  The Gloucester centre is the outstanding defensive 13 in the Six Nations. On Friday night he managed the world-class Virimi Vakatawa expertly, reaffirming his credentials. Harris reads the game superbly well and has the power to make dominant hits when required. He has come from left-field but is right in contention after Manu Tuilagi’s injury and an indifferent Six Nations for Henry Slade. Garry Ringrose looks set to be first choice at 13 but Harris could well edge out Jonathan Davies, George North or Slade to join him. The ability of Slade to cover numerous positions will undoubtedly make him a useful squad member, however.  Van der Merwe has made an instant impression on the international scene. The physically imposing winger beat 31 defenders in this year’s tournament, surpassing Brian O’Driscoll’s record for the most in a single edition of the Six Nations (30), which he set in 2000. His combination of power, footwork and finishing nous makes him a tempting option for Gatland. However, Van der Merwe also made a number of defensive mistakes in the Six Nations, looks a little shaky under the high ball and is inexperienced at the top level. If wing was an area of weakness for the Lions, Van der Merwe would be a shoo-in. But have his exploits over the last 12 months been impressive enough to displace one of Anthony Watson, Jonny May or Josh Adams?  The Edinburgh star could be directly competing with another wing sensation in Louis Rees-Zammit for the final spot. Van der Merwe would be an exciting pick, but this tour could be too early in his development as an international player.

The biggest sporting event currently taking place in the United States is a basketball tournament called “March Madness”. The term was first coined in 1939 by a high school official in relation to the excitement generated by the eight-team competition composed of colleges. Over the past 80 plus years, it has grown to a 68-team tournament lasting several weeks. The excitement has kept pace. In 2019, the competition generated roughly $1billion for the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) the organising body while $8.5billion is wagered on the results.  But the real mad part. The totally crazy part. The insane part. The athletes, who generate all these billions, do not receive a single dollar for their efforts. In fact, they are banned from receiving any “extra benefit or expense allowance not authorized by the NCAA legislation” which could extend to having a meal off campus or accepting sports clothing from a potential sponsor. This is not just basketball but all American college sports. College football, which is played in some of the biggest stadiums in the world, pulls in around $1.5 billion a year in television rights plus millions more in other forms of revenues. Again the athletes get paid nothing. As former NBA player Chris Paul wrote recently: “Can you imagine what it’s like to generate millions in revenue for your school — without being able to buy a hot meal off campus? Can you imagine what it’s like to be a few months from being able to take care of your family — but knowing that if you twist your leg at the wrong angle, you could lose it all?” All this could be about to change, however. On Wednesday the United States Supreme Court will hear a case brought by Shawn Alston, a former college football player for West Virginia University, which charges the NCAA with breaking anti-trust regulations. Effectively the colleges reap millions of dollars a year by colluding not to pay their athletes. The lower courts have already ruled in Alston’s favour. The NCAA’s traditional argument is that the athletes are receiving a free education through scholarship schemes. However, the education takes a back seat to the student’s athletic pursuits. It is estimated that athletes will spend 40 hours a week training, equivalent to a full-time job.  Unsurprisingly, the graduation rates for student athletes are far lower than for the general student population. Of course, the student athletes can go on to make millions in the NBA or NFL, but it is believed only 4 per cent of students will be drafted. They then must survive their mandatory rookie contract before they can get their big pay day. A severe injury could easily snatch that dream away. Meanwhile, coaches within college sports are paid millions.  The optics are not great. The football and basketball college athletes, who perform the labour, are predominantly black. Those that run the college programmes, who profit from those labours, are overwhelming white. At best, it is hard not to see this as a form of indentured servitude. In this year’s March Madness, athletes have taken to tweeting or displaying the hashtag #NotNCAAproperty. As Geo Baker of the Rutgers Scarlet Knights wrote: “We deserve an opportunity to create money from our name, image, and likeness. If you don't agree with that statement, then you are saying that you believe that I, a human being, should be owned by something else.” The NCAA continues to dig its heels in. Of course, when an industry makes billions of dollars, it is unwilling to give up that profit stream without a fight. Its fallback argument is that if you started paying athletes then it would blur the distinction between college and professional sports, which lead to a mass decline in viewership. This seems tenuous at best. Nor are the NCAA colleges particularly benevolent, far-sighted institutions. Just before March Madness, Oregon Ducks’ player Sedona Prince posted a video, which has been viewed 18 million times, of the difference between the women’s weights room consisting of 12 dumbbells and the men’s weights room, which was full of state of the art equipment.  Indeed, the very adoption of amateurism as a founding principle of NCAA was born of a historical wrong. In 1955 Ray Dennison died of an injury sustained playing American football for Fort Lewis A&M Aggies. When his widow sued for workers’ compensation, the NCAA successfully argued that as he was a student-athlete rather than a worker and therefore compensation should not be paid. Subsequently explicit pledges of amateurism were written into every college sporting contract.  It is high time the Supreme Court righted the wrong of this glaring injustice.

Last week, Women's Aid made a statement which went largely under the radar in football. The news was that Bristol City, a club which pledged its support for the domestic abuse charity's Football United campaign, had signed Danny Simpson - a man convicted in 2015 of assaulting his former partner and mother of one of his children. Women's Aid swiftly announced it would be removing City from all materials related to the Football United campaign, expressing its concern that Simpson will "be a role model for young fans and team-mates", adding: "In 2014 Bristol City signed our Football United pledge to say ‘We will send a clear message in our club that violence against women and children is completely unacceptable’, it sadly seems that in 2021 that this is not the case." When City announced Simpson would be joining the club until the end of the season, the accompanying statement described his football credentials, including five years at Leicester City where he won the Premier League. But in 2015, during that title winning season, Simpson was convicted of assault. During the trial evidence given by police included a description of him "choking" his former partner, after police entered his home in December 2014 to find Simpson "straddling" her, "his hands firmly placed around her neck". His former partner did not support the prosecution, and rescinded her original police statement, but Simpson was sentenced to 300 hours of community service for which he served 145, before a judge agreed that 'press intrusion' made completing his full service impossible, and instead imposed a 21-day curfew. This column is not here to question whether Simpson should or should not play elite football. But the way City sidestepped their new signing's inconvenient history is worth highlighting, as it is something they are not alone in. Players and journalists jostled to congratulate Simpson on Twitter, while news reports described a similar, edited synopsis of his career as City did. It is characteristic of a larger eerie silence across sport, in a month where violence against women has been at the centre of national discourse. While nobody would seek to deprive Simpson of his right to move on from such an incident, and the law allows him to do that, how much better would it have been when violence against women is so much in the public eye, for him and the club to have met that subject head on? When Sarah Everard went missing in Clapham in March, and was later found dead, a women's movement gained pace. The reaction to her tragic death dominated the front pages and social media in a national conversation, but barely a peep was heard from sport's major bodies and personalities. Trust Marcus Rashford to be the exception, tweeting:  Along with Chelsea, who have been applauded this past year for its campaign backing domestic abuse charity Refuge, Rashford's voice stood out because he cut a largely isolated figure in men's sport. Readers might wonder why such a story should have a place in the sports pages. But male perpetrators of violence and harassment do not exist in a vacuum, they are embedded in our culture - including sport. Former Real Madrid player Robinho was signed by three top division sides since his 2017 conviction for sexual assault and involvement in a gang rape - for which he has evaded any jail time due to extradition law. The NFL sparked outrage in 2014, when a video captured Baltimore Ravens player Ray Rice dragging his partner from a lift after knocking her unconscious. Rice initially only received a two-game suspension - a smaller penalty than that carried for ball tampering. Beyond the legal convictions, sports culture has demonstrated a disturbing attitude to violence against women in which beating up a woman is apparently something to laugh about. Last year, when domestic abuse cases surged in the middle of lockdown, British boxer   released a video where, in supposed jest, he advised men how to beat up their wives or girlfriends. He was fined £15,000 by the BBBofC after apologising, but served a mere four-month ban. While earlier this month, an image of Jurgen Klopp (which was used without his knowledge or consent) was widely circulated alongside the faces of real-life survivors of domestic abuse, with the caption: "Beaten at home throughout lockdown." There has long been evidence to show "significant rises" in domestic abuse claims during major international football tournaments where England is involved - including the 2018 World Cup, when 239 domestic abuse calls were made to police on or the day after England fixtures. It is why seeing Simpson take up his spot with City without the club issuing any commitment or acknowledgment of his troubling history makes a mockery of the efforts Women's Aid has made to overturn such links between football and male violence. It undermines the club's support of the charity, and suggests that a footballer's ability to kick a ball is more important than any values City claims to have around respecting the safety of women. It is, quite simply, sports washing at its finest. Both the club and Simpson declined to comment, but  understands City had been in close discussions with Women's Aid ahead of last week's announcement. However it came in the days after former City under-23s player, Alhaji Sesay, was given a 10-year prison sentence for rape and attempted rape after separate attacks on two women - another significant moment the club failed to acknowledge. "We would hope the club would want to send a clear message on respect, consent and healthy relationships for players," Women's Aid's statement said on the matter, adding: "One of the main ways we can [reduce violence against women] is by not ignoring or minimising violence against women where it happens." To those who say it is unfair to drag up Simpson's six-year-old conviction after he served his sentence would be ignoring the huge influence football and sport can have on an issue that affects women in all walks of life. How powerful would it be if more men in sport, as a collective, take up the mantle in supporting the other half of the population this once? Women's Aid was right to call out City's empty support - sport as a whole needs to acknowledge its responsibility to stand up and be counted in the conversation around women's safety and male violence.

Not only is Erling Haaland the most wanted striker in the world and a generational talent capable of improving the front line of any Champions League-chasing club, somehow, despite his age and incredible scoring form, he is (relatively) affordable due to the unique workings of his deal with Borussia Dortmund. The Norwegian international has a £68 million transfer release clause which activates in 2022, meaning it is in Dortmund’s interests to sell this summer and maximise their profit on a player who would inevitably leave in the near future anyway.  The likely £100m+ fee that would secure a move eliminates most clubs from the equation but a few sides will already be working out their budgets. The question for Haaland is, where he would best fit in?  Man City dominate matches with an entertaining style of play and are in particular need of a central striker now that Sergio Aguero has announced he will leave at the end of the season. In Pep Guardiola, Haaland would develop under one of the best coaches in the world and could make similar strides to those of Robert Lewandowski, a similarly powerful goal poacher who excelled as the No 9 in Guardiola’s possession-based 4-3-3.  City could certainly do with a presence in the box to give them something different in the final third, and although Haaland’s height and strength should allow him to bully defenders in the box, an area of the game which he can certainly improve upon is heading the ball. Whether a lack of aggression or technique, Haaland often doesn’t appear to attack crosses and high balls with the determination or (dare it be said) confidence required to beat defenders in the air, which helps explain why he has only taken eight headed shots at goal in the Bundesliga this season compared to Lewandowski’s 30. The player radars of both from this season's Champions League make for an interesting comparison: Lewandowski offers more in build-up and link play, as well as doing slightly more defensively (winning headers and making tackles and interceptions etc) - areas we can expect to see an improvement in from Haaland under Guardiola. Everything else about his game, particularly the intensity and desire to win the ball, suits what Guardiola demands of his centre forward.  Most obvious fit As a boyhood fan of Leeds, the city of his birth and another club his father Alfe Inge played for, a move to rivals United might go against Haaland's football loyalties were it not for the presence of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who worked with him at Molde.   United’s fast transition, counter-attacking style of play would suit Haaland’s movement and pace perfectly, able to lead the line and dart across the box like Edinson Cavani, but also to break and run directly at centre-backs like Marcus Rashford and Anthony Martial. Bruno Fernandes' tendency to shoot from long range can often result in goalkeepers parrying the ball into the path of an onrushing striker like Haaland. He offers a much more penetrative threat than Martial, as seen here: If you enter Rashford or Cavani into the search box above, you will see that Haaland's numbers make him really stand out as the kind of striker United would benefit from. Solskjaer’s fluid 4-2-3-1 would be much more dangerous with a genuine goal threat taking the chances created during the attacking moves they already perform so well. United are already the second-top scorers in the league without a consistent, clinical finisher.  Suits the style of football. Also a career path to Real Madrid There are few guarantees in football, but one Haaland might consider when evaluating a move to Chelsea is that he will almost certainly work under a few different managers at Stamford Bridge were he to move there. For now it's Thomas Tuchel, who likes to keep possession and press high but his Chelsea team hasn’t been prolific. That is both a problem for the manager and one that Haaland could benefit from. There is competition in Tammy Abraham, who hasn't shown enough in his game to cement first choice as No 9, Olivier Giroud (likely to leave), and the yet-to-adapt Timo Werner, but Haaland would instantly improve Chelsea and play every week. Chelsea would not have expected Werner's attacking contribution to be so small compared to a forward like Haaland: With the choice of any club in the world, the traditional insecurity of the manager’s position and his ties to the two Manchester clubs makes a move to London feel unlikely.   No Real Madrid aren’t exactly rolling in money at the moment but tend to find a way to secure the very best talent and are a club few players could, and would, turn down. One concern might be how badly Luka Jovic struggled to adapt to the demands of the club after signing, having lit up the Bundesliga before moving to Spain. He is now back on loan at Frankfurt with a record of two goals in 21 La Liga appearances. Even the best players can feel the weight of pressure at the Bernebeu. Another even more important issue is the transitional state of the team. Sergio Ramos, Toni Kroos, Luka Modric and Karim Benzema are all on the verge of retiring or leaving and at 20 years old, Haaland may be better placed to wait to join the world’s biggest club when it's in a better state. He is also a completely different sort of player to Benzema and the team would need to play differently as a result. Through-balls and crosses would become key, with Haaland more likely to run onto a pass and finish than Benzema, who is better able to float in and out of attacking moves to link with others.  Not the best career move right now PSG could offer Haaland all the money he could eat and oil he could drink as well as the near-guaranteed possibility of multiple trophy wins. Except for the odd surprise cup upset, PSG win almost every game domestically and are getting closer to achieving their ultimate ambition of a Champions League win too. Haaland would be well paid and able to score ridiculous amounts of goals in Ligue 1 in a terrifyingly-talented front three, but the prestige of, or simply Haaland’s interest in, French football will likely be a deciding factor.  That said, the opportunity to play alongside Neymar and Kylian Mbappe could be tempting.  Very wealthy stepping stone Makes the most logistical sense of all the moves as a step up to a bigger club in the same league from where he can make another transfer within 3-5 years having secured Bundesliga titles and legitimately competed for the Champions League. Whether Bayern have the funds, particularly after the financial difficulties caused by the pandemic, is another matter. Additionally, Lewandowski has scored 35 goals in 25 league games this season and doesn't exactly need to be replaced any time soon. At 32 years old he may even be at his peak, meaning Haaland would be in direct competition with a player already his superior.  Finances and Lewandowski prevent it being a good move

England almost dropped their first points of their World Cup qualifying campaign as they were pegged back by Poland at Wembley. But with the clock ticking towards 90 minutes, Harry Maguire proved to be the hero with a clinical shot from a corner.   kept a close eye on the match and ran the rule over Gareth Southgate's men. He has played in three qualifiers but has not been given much of a chance to impress. No saves to make in the first half and no chance with the equaliser.  Showed energy to get up and down the right flank and support attacks, while never looking troubled on his flank when Polish players ran at him. Had so much time on the ball but got dispossessed on his own 18-yard line and Poland were given a way back into the match. Set up the winner to redeem himself. Would have been happy that Robert Lewandowski was ruled out through injury. Carried the ball forward as England tried to chase a winner and volleyed in the deciding goal. Tidy defending, linked up well with Mason Mount and got a good cross over that Phil Foden almost scored from. Confidence-boosting selection with Luke Shaw’s excellent form recently.  Played a little further forward than his position with Leeds. He got around the pitch and took a knock to his ankle. Carried the ball forward well and showed excellent positional discipline. He was always positive with his passing rather than playing backwards. Happy to drop from his advanced position and get involved in play and was always a goal threat with his runs into the penalty area. Raced through and had effort saved.  Passed fit after missing training on eve of match and showed nice touches, knitted together the midfield and forwards with his smart passing. Sensed he had the beating of his full-back and kept running at him until he won a penalty. Guilty of being wasteful but carried the ball well. Tucked away his penalty with confidence and also had a decent drive saved by Wojciech Szczesny at the near post. Would have wanted better service but tireless work and was in dangerous positions.  James 86 (Foden) Calvert-Lewin 89 (Kane) Lingard 89 (Sterling)

For the last 12 months, tennis has emitted a low grumbling sound, like a diesel engine idling at the lights. Listen closely, and you can hear dozens of fit young athletes grousing about the misery of the pandemic: the cancelled tournaments, the reduced prize money, and above all the quarantines. Should we have sympathy for their plight, or should we pull out our imaginary violins? Well, it’s true that tennis has suffered more than any other major sport, because it is uniquely global – far more so than golf, for instance – and thus dependent on international travel. But then the players go and remind us how out of touch, and how monumentally selfish, many of them actually are. The latest instance came this week in Miami, where the enterprising  reporter Ben Rothenberg asked half-a-dozen press-conference guinea pigs whether they were planning to be vaccinated. He encountered a wall of scepticism. Not everyone is against. World No 2 Naomi Osaka said “I’m planning on getting one … whenever I’m eligible.” But Andrey Rublev and Elina Svitolina both stressed that there was no advantage to them in having a jab, as it wouldn’t save them from future bio-bubbles and quarantines. Meanwhile Aryna Sabalenka spouted some mumbo-jumbo about damage to the genetic code. Finally, Diego Schwartzman said “It's not a tradition in my family to get any vaccine” before later backtracking and blaming his English for any misunderstanding. The first thing to say here is that athletes are uniquely paranoid about what they put in their bodies. Indeed, they are taught to be that way by the World Anti-Doping Agency. So at a time when Germany has   over blood clot fears, one can forgive them for feeling twitchy. But then you look at their answers again, and blood clots make no appearance. The first two negatives cited a lack of personal advantage. This misses the fact that – for the young and healthy – vaccinations are not supposed to be about you. They are about the vulnerable people you could unintentionally infect. You can see the personal logic here. For the likes of Rublev and Svitolina, stepping off the tour to get a jab will lead to lost training days and travel issues. From a pragmatic perspective, the experience of actually contracting the virus is likely to be so trivial that they would be better off picking it up on the road. What this position ignores is that infection makes them a danger to public health. And then there is Sabalenka, who said “There is the two [vaccines], and I want to make the one I think is more expensive and the one is not going to your genetic stuff.” This sounds like a half-baked theory found on the internet. It thus fits in with the pattern of   since he became tennis’s first vaccine sceptic just under a year ago. We could point to a different kind of contagion here; that of bogus, pseudo-scientific ideas. Tennis once again finds itself uniquely vulnerable, to misinformation this time. The players are headstrong young athletes who run their own mini-team of coaches, physios and fitness trainers. It’s hard for their support staff to guide them when they make all the money and call all the shots. Yes, you could say the same about golfers. But tennis players tend to leave school earlier, often before puberty, and thus complete very little formal education. Rothenberg’s questions prompted enough debate around the world for both tours to issue a statement. The Women’s Tennis Association said that they were not interested in interfering because “this is a personal decision we respect.” The men’s tour are talking to “consultants in infectious disease and virology”. Sooner or later, one expects that a big event – perhaps it could be next year’s Australian Open – will make vaccinations essential, and thus nudge the player base into complying for their own selfish reasons. For the moment, though, many members of the locker-room are coming across as narcissistic and blinkered. The one person who has judged the public mood from the beginning is Rafael Nadal. In Melbourne, for instance, he undercut the chorus of outrage at two-week lockdowns by saying “You see how many people are losing their father, their mums, without having the chance to say goodbye … When you see all of this, you have to stay a little bit more positive.” Nadal is a  , someone who sees family and community as the most important values. You might remember him helping to clean up his home island of Majorca after deadly floods swept the capital a couple of years ago. His peers have less life experience, for many have spent their entire lives in another sort of bubble: that provided by their agent, coach and trainer. Even so, they have had a year to consider the implications of the pandemic. And now they have switched from bemoaning their personal suffering to denigrating the only solution. There is something curiously childlike in this contradiction.

There is only one appropriate response to the news that   in a World Cup qualifier: to point out it was a good job they weren’t playing the whole of Macedonia.  Sure, it is not the most original of gags, first employed when the Welsh rugby team lost a World Cup game against Western Samoa in 1991. But that shouldn’t hold us back. Not when it is Germany involved — and particularly when history suggests this is a blip rather than a long-term slump.  This, after all, is the nation that routinely roasts minnows, the country that has won the World Cup no less than four times. Here’s how certain and secure their progress normally is: until yesterday’s defeat, they hadn’t lost a qualification match at home in 20 years, when they were beaten 5-1 by England in 2001, a result that we in this country have politely tried not to mention too often since.  And here they were — for 90 minutes at least — proving to be as flawed as the rest of us. To add to the comedy, the Macedonians’ opening goal was scored by the oldest man ever to find the net against them, 37-year-old Goran Pandev. What’s more this was promoted before kick-off as the final, triumphal home game to be overseen by the Germans’ long-serving, World Cup-winning coach, the trouser-rummaging Joachim Low. It is not a result to be sniffed at. Some might suggest it is a little rich to mock. Particularly if you are English and have seen your side humiliated by Iceland in Nice or be hammered by, well, Germany in Bloemfontein. But if anyone will understand the urge to titter at another’s misfortune it is the Germans. After all, their language accommodates the perfect term for the moment, a phrase so exact in its meaning it is impossible to translate. And Schadenfreude is a key element of a tribal football fan’s existence: sniggering when your rivals falter is as satisfying as celebrating your own team’s success. Just ask anyone in Scotland how they felt when England slumped to Croatia in the 2018 World Cup semi-final. The saltires were flying that night.  We on this side of the Channel don’t often get the opportunity to laugh at the Germans. For them making their way to the finals of a football competition is usually the most serene and easy of processes.
