So we should seize the rare chance to make merry about the fact the most coveted and highly paid bunch of players in Europe fell down against the latest incarnation of the long, drawn-out breakdown of Yugoslavia. Sure, North Macedonia are no fools and can field players of the calibre of Ezgjan Alioski of Leeds United. But a side featuring the likes of Ilkay Gundogan, Timo Werner and Leroy Sane were expected to swipe them aside with the minimum of fuss.  That they didn’t can only be greeted with delight by those of us who like to think we are their rivals. Particularly in a World Cup qualification process designed principally to ensure the progress of the big nations and their television audiences. Meaning has been almost completely extracted from a system in which the top sides are protected and qualification turned into one long procession of certainty.  Not any more. The North Macedonians saw to that. Except, being football fans, our instinct is not to praise their achievement so much as to smirk at German incompetence. Watching Werner miss the kind of sitter that would give a weekend park player palpitations, or reading the Group J table and seeing them in third place adds a wholly unexpected spice to competition. It is almost as if Low and his team hail from a country that couldn’t organise a roll-out in a vaccination centre.  So laugh loud and long. Particularly as, when it comes to Germany, such opportunities do not linger long. Their response to set-back tends to be short, sharp and productive. Only the foolish would suggest this is a result likely to do anything other than spark an insistent revival; the wise have probably already placed a bet on them triumphing in Qatar next winter.  After all, the last time they faltered at home in qualification, they went on to reach the final of the 2002 World Cup. England — their conquerors in Munich on that glorious night in 2001 — lost in the quarter-finals. Their previous home qualifying defeat — to Portugal in 1985 — prefaced the exact same scenario, with Die Mannschaft eventually being edged out in the 1986 World Cup final by Argentina, who had beaten England in the last eight thanks to Diego Maradona's brilliant feet and wandering hands. Which was nothing to laugh at all. Unless you happen to be Scottish, obviously.

It is no mean feat to be quietly effective in a team whose every move is dissected, analysed and reanalysed, but Kalvin Phillips has been just that in England’s first three games of World Cup qualifying. And Phillips, who – ahead of the latest triple-header – might have still worried for his place if Jordan Henderson recovers from injury in time for the summer, can now be confident that he is a certainty for Gareth Southgate’s squad for the European Championships. Mason Mount, Phil Foden and Declan Rice are the midfielders who have grabbed most of the headlines over the past week, but Phillips has made his own impact and is clearly valued highly by Southgate. Leeds United supporters may have had mixed feelings over seeing Phillips start all three of England’s three qualifiers, but they will be proud at the way the 25-year-old carried himself. And when the real test came in the form of Poland at Wembley,  by completing 100 per cent of his first-half passes, 26 from 26, in another encouraging performance. It was from his corner that Harry Maguire eventually smashed England’s winner. Phillips did not look like a player who was making only his seventh England appearance and it has been striking how comfortably he has settled into the squad, having first been called up before he had played in the Premier League. “He’s adapted really well” said Southgate. “He’s a fantastic character to have around, a fantastic athlete and he uses the ball really well.” It is testament to how impressed Southgate has been with Phillips that he reverted to a back four for all three qualifiers, resisting the temptation to bring in a third central defender for the greater threat offered by Poland. Henderson’s potential absence for the Euros looked like a huge blow and Southgate will still be keen to have him available against Croatia on June 13. But if Henderson does not make it or is not quite fit enough for the early games, then Southgate knows that, in Phillips, he appears to have found the right man to step in. That in itself may be doing the Leeds star a disservice, as he has proved himself to be far more than an able deputy. While Mount and Foden catch the eye with their ability to create and score goals, and Rice is in many ways the intelligent muscle in front of the back four, Phillips can help build attacks with his range of passing, making himself available to the defenders and pushing forwards to support the attacking players. He is also savvy enough to smell danger. The social media trolls who have been forced to find a new target by Mount’s superb form have tried to turn their attention towards Phillips, using his inclusion as another way of trying to accuse Southgate of being negative. That may be largely down to club rivalries, but one senses that Phillips, in probably a more understated manner, will eventually send his online detractors packing in much the same way Mount has done. In terms of England, only one opinion needs to matter to Phillips. And, in Southgate, he has earned himself a big fan.

The narrative of John Stones’ reinvention has been a seductive one this season. There is his golden form at Manchester City, his thriving double act with Ruben Dias in central defence, his hopes of sealing a fresh contract with the champions-in-waiting. But then,  , his stock fell faster than Deliveroo’s share price. Where England’s favourite takeaway service suffered a 30 per cent wipe-out in value on its first day as a listed company, its once flavour-of-the-month centre-back risked a similar collapse in worth in Gareth Southgate’s eyes, as his reputation for brittleness returned. Ultimately, the damage was mitigated by Harry Maguire’s late winner, but the horror of a single absent-minded error will haunt Stones’ thoughts for weeks. His dawdling on the ball gifted a touch to Arkadiusz Milik, and within seconds Brighton’s Jakub Moder completed the punishment with a rifled finish beyond Nick Pope. Even if there were no supporters in attendance to barrack him, a crestfallen Stones still looked as if he wanted the Wembley pitch to swallow him whole. It was his first such blunder in seven weeks, but with England’s next engagement on this stage a Euro 2020 group game against Croatia in 74 days’ time, the timing was heavy with misfortune. Stones was supposed to have left brain-fades such as this far behind. Granted, there had been ample support for his ‘Calamity John’ reputation: an absurd back-pass across his own penalty area for City in October 2016, a horrible miscue to allow Roberto Firmino to score for Liverpool in January 2018. He had been culpable on the international stage, too, slipping at a fateful moment against Holland in 2019. All this had become a distant memory, thanks to his renaissance under Pep Guardiola. At 26, his sheer consistency in defence played a vital role in City’s , with the manager understood to be keen to extend his contract beyond 2022. His improvements appeared a testament to how honest graft could turn around a once-faltering career. But then a fleeting lapse for his country brought back an unwelcome caricature. It was for his gaffe-prone tendency that Guardiola used to look askance at Stones. Any player prone to slips in possession had no part in his quest for perfection. But by degrees, Stones won over even his most committed detractors. All the entries in his reel of lowlights, from an under-hit backpass to Tim Howard while he was still in Everton colours to a poorly-aimed clearance that let in Daniel Sturridge to score for Liverpool in a Mersey derby rout, were consigned to history. Then came this stumble against Poland, and the question of whether he could be trusted for the grandest occasions resurfaced. By the end, Stones had achieved some measure of atonement, cushioning a header across to Maguire for the winner. “He has made a mistake, and he knows that,” Southgate said. “But he has bounced back.” The head coach is not the impetuous type, and he is unlikely to countenance any drastic action on Stones, with England safely en route to qualifying for the Qatar World Cup. But inescapably, a shadow of doubt will linger. Come June, Southgate needs to have banished any last nagging concerns, settling on a starting line-up who can lift a restless country. Is Stones a player who can produce when it matters most? There is no question that the pressure on England increases vastly from here. When they next emerge from the Wembley tunnel, Southgate’s England team hope, like all of us, to inhabit a demonstrably different world. For all that they have grown inured to keeping the show rolling on through this tumbleweed period for the national game, they are soon to be the headline stars of a summer of love that will, to judge by this week’s lockdown-loosening revelries, make Woodstock look like a tea party. Kane, while he embodied composure in lashing home his penalty against Poland, is about to discover how it felt being Paul Gascoigne 25 years ago. Everywhere, you can sense the pent-up Euro 96 energies just waiting to be unleashed. Even Sir Keir Starmer, whose greatest sporting claim to fame is as a “midfield general” for his eight-a-side team at his local Kentish Town sports centre, has not resisted leaping aboard the nostalgia train, choosing “Three Lions” as his first track on Radio Four’s  Rocking has been conspicuous by its absence at Wembley of late, as indeed has jumping, cheering, even unrestricted breathing. To imagine that all this can be reimagined in 2½ months as a fan-friendly citadel is a stretch. This, though, remains the intention. Against Croatia, there will be legal permission for at least 10,000 to attend, with all restrictions on social contact due to be wound down eight days later. It is an occasion to which England need to rise, after being granted a major reprieve by Poland. Stones, likewise, must adapt, and fast. For his club, he has successfully mastered his fragilities. But for his country, there is still the suspicion he is an accident waiting to happen.  John Stones has an age to turn and play forward when he receives the ball from Nick Pope.  But instead of going forward the Manchester City defender turns back towards goal when closed down by Moder  Under pressure Stones miscontrols the ball and only succeeds in stabbing it inside to the grateful Milik.   Stones goes to close him down but the crafty Milik slips it through his legs to Moder.   Brighton's Moder opens his body on the left of the box and bludgeons a shot past Pope, who has little chance to stop it.

The key question for Harry Kane is: what next? Once more the Tottenham Hotspur striker has proved his excellence and, arguably, he can lay claim to being not only the best centre-forward in the Premier League but also its most effective play-maker. His eye for a pass, and weight of pass, is as effective as his finishing and it is remarkable just how much Tottenham are dependent upon him. If only Kane could pass to Kane. Which leads to that question of what next?   – although they will have to overcome Manchester City in the League Cup Final to do so. And even then is winning the fourth most important competition, from the four that Spurs entered, going to be enough to keep Kane happy? The short answer is he may have little choice. There are three more years on his contract after this season, he turns 28 in July, and that is before even thinking about whether a club would come close to the by Spurs chairman Daniel Levy. Or want to negotiate with Levy in the first place. There is little doubt Kane, given his ambition, given his ability, would consider a change and it has been on his mind for more than two years now but there is another factor:   this summer when transfers will undoubtedly still be affected by the coronavirus pandemic? Clubs want him but can they do it? One thing is for sure – Kane will not allow the speculation to affect him. He is one of the most dedicated and single-minded footballers and has worked tirelessly to maximise his ability for club and country even if, at times, his frustration is not only inevitable but obvious. Kane may well surpass not only Wayne Rooney’s record as England’s leading goalscorer  . But how will that feel if he does not win trophies? Shearer could have won far more if he had joined Manchester United instead of Newcastle United but, at least, by then he was already a Premier League winner with Blackburn Rovers. For Kane there may also be the nightmare scenario of another season outside of the Champions League – having lost in the final two years ago – should Spurs finish outside the top four once again. It is not where elite players want to be. The questions and the debate will continue but Kane should be celebrated, also, for what he is and that is an extraordinarily accomplished forward who has – as all the best players do – continually adapted and added to his game. Interestingly he always out-performs his ‘xG’ – expected goals – one of the favoured metrics used by analysts. It means he scores more than he should. Kane has 27 goals and 16 assists in 40 games so far this season for Spurs, which equates to more than one goal involvement a game, and his link-up with Son Heung-min . And yet Spurs are only sixth in the league and out of Europe. It does raise one more question: what he would achieve in a team that is truly challenging for honours?

A combination of factors – Brexit, the coronavirus-induced financial issues – have led to changing the way that football clubs at the very top of the game do business. Here, Jason Burt examines the significant ways and how it will effect clubs and players.  “In a healthy market, the natural instinct for a club is to prevent players from going inside their last year of contract,” says leading agent Alan Redmond, the head of football at , the company founded by rapper Jay-Z, and whose clients include Marcus Rashford, Kevin De Bruyne, Romelu Lukaku and Wilfried Zaha. "It maintains the rights of the club to sell the player, rather than lose him for free or for a greatly reduced fee.” However, that has changed with clubs dealing with the loss of income due to Covid and considering how best to manage their squads. It means there may be far more free agents and – therefore – free transfers in the summer, including some high-profile ones. , Bayern Munich's David Alaba and Jerome Boateng and Paris Saint-Germain's Julian Draxler are all free agents in the summer, while some Premier League clubs have swathes of their squads out of contract. Crystal Palace, for one, have 11 in that position come June 30. “The question that a lot of clubs will have now regarding players inside their last year of contract is: ‘does the wage cost of renewing the player for another three years outweigh the risk of not being able to sell him and the financial implications of being saddled with him for an extended period?’” Redmond says. “Clubs will ask themselves if they could use the funds to bring fresh faces, rather than go through the motions of renewing a player of questionable re-sale value. Fans of clubs with multiple players on soon-to-expire contracts may normally question the management of their club. In the specific case of the summer 2021 transfer window, your club may be wise in this respect.” One continuing advantage that Premier League clubs have over the rest of Europe is the strength of the broadcast deals. Europe envies the spending power in England which, Redmond says, provides the “opportunity of a swifter financial recovery even if that means it just enables them to borrow more easily than European clubs with the same empty stadiums but vastly inferior TV deals”. In the first instance that should make it easier for   despite the UK having left the European Union – although they will have to navigate the ‘points-based’ system which has been introduced. If players are to be signed they have to meet a set of criteria based on such measures as international appearances, which league the selling club is in and how many competitive games they have played. “The challenge facing Premier League clubs is to work through the ‘points-based system’ and figure out who the hell they can actually sign?” Redmond says. But this also does provide an opportunity. “In the way that clubs like   of their competitors in terms of data analysis and the transfer market, Premier League clubs who adapt to the new system fastest can steal a march on other clubs,” Redmond explains. “I think there are some clubs who have reacted sharply and are attacking the situation with an intelligent approach, as others are still yawning while putting their pants on. At Roc Nation, we represent a non-EU player who has played once for his national team. In January, we calculated the points to see if he met the 15-point barrier to play in England. He actually gets 28 points, almost double the requirement. Meeting the requirement to play in the UK adds to the player’s value. This is a time for brains in player recruitment, more than ever.” The idea of so-called ‘feeder clubs’, where players can be developed or sent on loan, is not new. Chelsea have long cultivated relationships with clubs such as Vitesse Arnhem to develop players through loan deals, while Manchester City have used their network of clubs around the world to blood their younger talents.  Redmond believes that more Premier League clubs will look to develop this route. “There is a chance that an increasing number of Premier League owners will acquire an additional European club,” he says. “One of the many possible advantages of this could be to sign players who fall below the points threshold in the UK, in the same way that prior to Brexit, it was a method of signing non-EU players in territories with less stringent visa regulations. “The issue with feeder clubs is that they are often small clubs in small markets. Players transferred to them may struggle to meet the criteria to play in England, even after two strong seasons. However, there’s nothing preventing these players from being sold into other countries at a profit. Additionally, feeder clubs are often used as loan destinations for young, not first team-ready, players signed to the mother club.” However the system is not without controversy and does not always work, if there is not a coherent plan or style of play. “This hodge-podge of crossed purposes often stomps on the identity of the feeder club itself, as the coach is left to select his starting XI from a combination of home-grown players, nomadic players bought for investment, and shoe-horned loans from the mother club that they’re under pressure to play," Redmond says. "And this is all while trying to stay rooted to the footballing philosophy being force-fed by the club at the top of the hierarchy. Some clubs will get it right. A lot won’t.” Redmond is confident that optimism is finally beginning to return, with a few caveats. “The   but this wasn’t a surprise to anyone,” he says. “In the summer of 2020, there was a sense that fans would be back in stadiums by the end of the year, even if it was in reduced numbers, and that we would come into 2021 with attendances being increased further. “The January window was always likely to be restrained but when it became apparent that fans wouldn't be returning imminently, there was a quiet acceptance within the game that while televised football was playing an important role for millions of locked-down people, nobody was likely to spend until there were more concrete signs of recovery. “Everyone is afraid to jump the gun and presume that we’re over the worst but that is the supposition that is forming the consensus within football and fuelling talks for the summer window.  With the positivity around vaccinations being rolled out, the reality of contracts expiring and, dare we say it, fans returning, I can see an active summer window.” The nature of a number of transfers will change, Redmond argues, with clubs thinking more creatively about how they can get deals done – with the fees paid coming down.  “Just as Neymar’s world record (€222 million) transfer to PSG partially reset transfer fees at the top end, and contributed to prices like those paid for Philippe Coutinho and Antoine Griezmann, the effects of Covid sent things back in the opposite direction more profoundly,” he explains. “I would still anticipate some big transfers in the summer, as well as some substantial deals that involve part-exchange. A player who was valued, pre-Covid, at £50 million, may not go for £50 million this summer. He may, however, go for £30 million plus a player worth £8-12 million in the opposite direction. Again, exchange deals are nothing new but I can see them being advantageous for both clubs in a transaction in this specific summer window.”

Two years ago, Gareth Southgate explained the absence of James Maddison from the England squad by saying that the team “had not been playing with a No 10”. The world has changed since then and so have England, for whom the main development of these past few games has been the emergence of not one, but two No 10s in Southgate’s starting lineup.  and Poland, England’s attack was far more fluid than we have come to expect. Out went the rigidity that was caused by a back three and in came a flexibility in the final third, where Mason Mount and Phil Foden were given the freedom to seek space and play between the lines. For the first 45 minutes  , England looked to be playing a genuinely modern and progressive form of attacking football. Foden drifted inside from the right, combining with his team-mates and helping England to outnumber the visiting midfield, while Kyle Walker provided the width on the flank he had vacated. It was an approach built on movement, intelligence and technical quality in the attacking midfield positions. Which, in short, are all the things that England have been routinely accused of lacking in recent years. There was none of this against Croatia in the World Cup semi-final of 2018, for example, when Luka Modric’s most devastating act was to remind an entire nation that they did not have a Luka Modric. Mount and Foden are not at that level, although they might be one day. They certainly play that sort of football, though: roaming, scheming, controlling the tempo and dragging opposition players into the places they do not want to go.  Completing the trident behind Harry Kane was Raheem Sterling, whose role is to stretch teams with his pace rather than drift around with Mount and Foden. Together they have made for an appealing trio in these last two matches, when there has been an exciting balance to England’s attacking play at times. Their first goal against Poland, eventually finished from the penalty spot by Kane, was a fine example of the Foden/Mount/Sterling triumvirate in action. Foden had floated over from his starting position on the right, as he did throughout the first half, to create a tight triangle with Mount and Sterling: The ball was lost, but Foden’s proximity to the action allowed him to win it back and prod a pass into Sterling. From there, the Manchester City winger embarked on the run which earned the penalty.  At the moment Sterling received the ball, both Mount and Foden were within just a couple of yards of him. Such a scenario would be far less likely with a player like Marcus Rashford or Jadon Sancho on the right flank.  , a player who generally wants to come to the ball in the middle of the pitch rather than wait for it on the wing. This could be seen again a few minutes after the opener, when Foden once again darted inside to create a shooting chance for Kane. Mount and Sterling had combined down the left, before the Chelsea midfielder whipped a pass into the path of Foden. Kane seized on Foden’s flick, and almost doubled the lead: In these early stages, when the plan was working, Mount and Foden had the protection of Declan Rice and Kalvin Phillips behind them. Together, they sometimes created what is referred to as a “box” in midfield. Rice and Phillips formed the deeper half of the square, with Mount and Foden playing directly in front of them. It meant England had depth, allowing them to smoothly play their way into the final third. Based on the events of the last week, this shape is the grand vision in Southgate’s mind. Replace Kalvin Phillips with Jordan Henderson, and it could easily be the midfield quartet of choice in the summer.  In such a scenario, it would not be unreasonable to suggest that Sterling, Rashford, Sancho and Jack Grealish are all competing for one place on the left wing. If Foden is the big winner of this international break, as the only player of his type on the right side, then those three surely must be seen as the biggest losers. All this is not to say that Southgate has cracked it. Far from it. The first half against Poland was promising, yes, but the second half was poor. The midfield began to soften, with Phillips and Rice coming under more pressure, and as a result Mount and Foden became less influential.  The opening 45 minutes was proof that England have an exciting plan, then, but the rest of the match showed they are not yet capable of executing it for a full 90 minutes. Southgate’s reluctance to make any changes until the 86th minute, when he replaced Foden with Reece James, was puzzling in the extreme. If this system, with Foden and Mount operating as two unconventional No 10s, is to be the Plan A, then one suspects that England will probably need a Plan B soon enough. For now, though, the optimists can seize upon the fluidity of their first-half showing as proof of this young team’s evolution into a more imaginative and flexible side. After all, it is not so long ago that Southgate’s England did not have any creative playmakers at all. With Foden and Mount, they now have two.

Germany has reacted with fury after their national team suffered a shock 2-1 defeat to North Macedonia in their World Cup Group J qualifier. The Germans controlled the game but failed to convert their chances against opponents ranked 65th in the world and were punished. Goran Pandev, 37, opened the scoring for North Macedonia when he was left unmarked in the box to tap home in first-half stoppage time. In the 63rd minute, Leroy Sane was brought down in the box and Ilkay Gundogan stepped up to equalise for Germany from the penalty spot. But with five minutes left, Eljif Elmas scored to spark scenes of mass celebration for the Balkan country. It was Germany's first home World Cup qualifying loss in 20 years in what was also coach Joachim Loew's last qualifying game in charge ahead of his departure following this summer's European Championship. "This is bitterly disappointing," Löew said after the match. "We were not fresh enough, we made mistakes. When we played quickly we were dangerous but we did not find the tools to be really threatening. "Overall, it was disappointing to lose like that at home." Gundogan, who has been in outstanding form for Manchester City, added: "This cannot ever happen. They had two chances, twice in front of our goal and twice they scored. It was just too easy. "We dominated had our chances but scored just once. To leave a man twice unmarked in the box should not happen." North Macedonia coach Igor Angelovski said: "These lads have made North Macedonia proud against the winners of four World Cup titles and three European championships. "We’ve never beaten a team with so many titles. Now we have to get some rest as what we have accomplished still hasn’t sunk in."     While there was despair in the media, the internet responded with delight at Germany's downfall.

The weather has turned, the clocks have changed, the referees have their swingometers in favour of the attack; when those ingredients are added to the quirkiest and strangest Champions Cup we have ever witnessed my excitement goes through the roof. There are three games where we could see 100 points and almost all eight are too close to call. I have predicted just one English team to go through, but it is not beyond the realms of possibility for all five to progress – or even zero. Of my eight selections, I would put money on three, the rest I would just be enjoying. After the impact of Covid and the worry of restrictions and cancellations, the sooner the tournament arrived at the knockouts the better. The need to finish the tournament and crown a European champion meant sacrificing the group stages and bailing on them as quickly as possible. That was a move of which  ; in the pool stage they played two, lost two, finished with a negative points difference and yet find themselves travelling to South Wales on Sunday in a European knockout match. There is nothing like knockout rugby – and we, the viewers, will benefit most. I love jeopardy! I watched the Pro14 final against Munster last Saturday which Leinster won 16-6, but it could have been 66-6. Munster know how to stay in a game, which is a valuable quality, but Leinster were unbelievable, playing with frightening pace and tempo. , centre Robbie Henshaw looks as if he is playing against 16-year-olds. The only negative you can aim at Leinster is a lack of ruthlessness given how many sights on goal they crafted. Toulon battered Sale at home and have rockstars like lock Eben Etzebeth throughout, but missing wing Gabin Villière is massive. He is so good; in fact, if he were playing I might have altered my prediction. Without him, they have no chance.  Leinster to win - easily La Rochelle are unlucky that they have played two and ‘won’ two and still have to go away from home, but they are victims of the proliferation of French teams left in the competition. Had this match been in France, I wouldn’t have given Gloucester a hope. However, if my auntie had proverbials she would be my uncle; at home, Gloucester have enough mercurial talent to upset the French aristocrats. But this La Rochelle team are formidable. English rugby viewers are aware of Will Skelton's potency and I’m such a fan of  . They have an amazing back-line but, as in 2018 when they reached their only quarter-final to date, their ability to close out matches, particularly with their goal-kicking, is a worry. But they are a European giant awaiting a wake-up, a real guilty pleasure. La Rochelle Wasps have lost five on the trot at home and, in that position, Clermont might be the last team they’d like to see rock up in Coventry. The French side beat Bristol away and were 21-0 up at one stage, but conversely they threw away a 28-16 lead to Munster at home. Regardless of the victor, this could almost be a rerun of Liverpool vs Newcastle in the Kevin Keegan era. Only one team scored more points than Clermont in the pool stages, but only one team conceded more points, too. This could be 75-70! Wasps have a few missing but they will take heart from that pool-stage win against Montpellier. But this is a competition in which Clermont have underachieved for years. They will not underestimate Wasps and, with that Penaud-Raka-Matsushima back three, it might not matter even if they do. Clermont What an advert for the competition to get matches of this quality in the last-16 stage. Munster have shown characteristic resilience lately, against Leinster and in Clermont – with Peter O’Mahony the catalyst, as ever – and they are at home. But they will need to be at their European best. Toulouse will arrive almost with a World XV. The French giants have the Six Nations’ best player,  , and look back to their self-confident best, having been missing in Europe for too long. But even a silent Thomond Park is worth 10 points. Most will think I’m nuts, but Munster will want to do it  . It breaks my heart to snub Toulouse's magnificence but backing Munster at home has similarities with Phil Taylor in the darts or Desert Orchid in the King George - it always feels a safe bet.  Munster, but it will be tight If Sale are the luckiest team in the competition, then Lyon are the unluckiest. Unbeaten so far, putting Gloucester through the mincer in the pool stages, their reward is a trip to the champions who themselves finished seventh in their pool. The casual viewer might think that this is a done deal for Exeter, at home against a team of little European repute. But Lyon are the Top 14’s form team; they have won their last three matches, with Toulon and Toulouse among them. Exeter   and if Lyon fly out of the blocks on Saturday to expose any hint of rustiness then it could be a tough afternoon. The Chiefs have not been at their fluid best this season – but they are a big-game team.  Exeter Edinburgh simply have nothing to lose and, when you add in some of Richard Cockerill’s mongrel, that makes for a dangerous underdog. This could be uncomfortable for Racing, who will be without banned fly-half Finn Russell. They will want it to be finished after 50 minutes so they can slope off for a glass of fizz. Edinburgh will have to piggy-back the Scottish heroics of last weekend if they are to replicate the result in the same city. No 8 Nick Haining was fabulous against France, so too  . For those  , too, this could be their last high-pressure match to stake their claim.  Racing 92 A lot of this will depend on the fitness of Matthieu Jalibert, the Bordeaux fly-half who missed France’s final Six Nations match due to concussion. If he plays, alongside wing Santiago Cordero, then that duo can rip anyone – even Bristol – to shreds. But the Bears have shred-ripping players of their own, too. Semi Radradra and Charles Piutau among others might have something to say about my verdict, but what is more certain is that this could be another 100-pointer. Bristol don’t know how to kick – and it seems to be working. But Bordeaux have Europe's best support lines and the Bears, for all their attacking glamour, must concentrate on stopping Bordeaux’s offloading. A team beginning with B will win this game – I’m sure. If Bristol do win, with a home quarter-final to come, they almost become tournament favourites. But it’s some challenge – Bordeaux seldom lose at home.  Bordeaux to nick it The organisers will be hoping that Scarlets do them a favour and put Sale away. As much as I would love Alex Sanderson’s side to lift the trophy after not winning a pool game, it would not be the greatest look for the competition. Might Sanderson have one eye on the Premiership top four and, after a lucky qualification, treat this as a shot to nothing? If Sale travel to Wales locked and loaded, if Faf de Klerk and Lood de Jager play and Akker van der Merwe nails his lineouts, then they have a sniff. But Scarlets had an amazing win at Bath playing stylish rugby, and a lot of their lads will be high on confidence after Wales’ Six Nations win.  Scarlets

The first major of the season begins on Wednesday, with Mel Reid labelling the Ana Inspiration as “the female Masters” and declaring that she has never felt more  .  finished seventh at this £2.25 million showpiece last September, her best finish at Palm Springs in seven appearances. It was a turnaround in form for the Englishwoman then ranked 108th in the world, and she continued the dramatic improvement with a fifth-placed finish in her next start  There have been two more top-12s since for the world No  37 and a fine display in the first three rounds at Carlsbad last week, that left her in second with 18 holes to play. Alas, five dropped shots in three holes from the 12th forced Reid back into a tie for 26th but, as she said: “I have to take the positives from those first 54 holes. “To be honest, it was nice to see the hard work paying off. Jorge [Parada, her coach] and I had really been putting in the hours,” Reid said. “I missed the cut in Lake Nona last month and was really unhappy with the way I was hitting it. Jorge and I grinded on the range and I played half decent in Ocala the next week. There was a lot of good stuff in Carlsbad and I came here pretty confident.” Reid, a proven Solheim Cup performer, admits she is at her best when the glare is at its most fierce. Of course, the absence of fans at Mission Hills Country Club – at the 50th anniversary of the tournament that some will forever call the Dinah Shore Classic – means this will be another eerie affair, but the event’s status ensures that the competitors will experience what Reid terms “that special feeling”. “We will, because let’s face it, this is our version of the Masters, ‘the female Masters’ if you like,” she said.  “We come back to the same course every year, the caddies wear the boiler suits and the major has its own traditions, like the winner jumping in Poppie’s Pond behind the 18th green. “And the course is amazing and always brings drama. It’s in immaculate shape year in, year out. And because we return here on an annual basis, the memories are written large, just as they are at Augusta. “I always recall Webby [Australia’s Karrie Webb in 2006] holing out for an eagle on the 18th to get into a play-off and then birdieing the same hole again to beat Lorena [Ochoa]. “The place has a history of spectacular moments on the last three holes and it would be incredible to pen my own piece of history. I absolutely love this course and am glad I finally played well here in 2020, because I think it suits my game, in that you have to hit a lot of greens to contend. There’s no excuse on the putting, the balls are rolling beautifully.” Anyone who has followed Reid’s career since she leapt into the sport’s consciousness in 2007 at St Andrews as a teenage amateur finishing in the top 16 of the Women’s British Open, will be thrilled that she is at last fulfilling her potential. The death of her mother, Joy, in a car crash in 2012, pressed pause on her progress as she struggled with grief. The six-time Ladies European Tour winner earned a LPGA card in 2017 and with a third at the Women’s PGA Championship 18 months ago highlighted her enduring quality. Perhaps Reid was fortunate that the UK media had the rise of her younger countrywomen Charley Hull and Georgia Hall on whom to concentrate, as she was allowed to carry on grafting in the shadows and forming a backroom staff that, as well as Parada, includes fitness trainer Ken Macdonald, sports psychologist Howard Falco and last, but probably foremost, caddie Ryan “Desi” Desveaux. “It’s been a long time in the making, but at last I feel like I have some sort of formula and that my best years are still ahead of me,” she said. “I’m just extremely happy with my team and think they understand me and what I need. Desi is on the bag and we’ve become a great team. I have so many goals – this year’s Solheim Cup, the Olympics, which I’ve been very vocal about. I suppose there’s one way to achieve all those aims in one week.”

Do Prince Harry and Meghan Markle have an Oscar in their sights? The latest hire for their Archewell media company is Ben Browning, an independent film producer whose work includes current   nominee  .  Announced Monday, Browning will be the head of content for Archewell Productions and Archewell Audio, guiding their partnerships with   and Spotify. The Sussexes signed a multi-year deal with the streamer in September 2020, and made another with   late last year. According to Forbes, a mutual contact in the entertainment industry recommended Browning, and multiple meetings followed, during which Harry and Meghan discussed their ambition to connect with a young, worldwide audience. That seems to be borne out by Browning’s statement this week, in which he said that was attracted by the couple’s vision for Archewell as “a global production company that will spotlight diverse voices and share uplifting stories.” The Archewell Netflix deal is for a variety of programming, including scripted and unscripted TV series, documentaries, feature films and children’s shows. Their Spotify deal is for them to both produce and host podcasts that uplift and entertain, kicked off by their   in December. So, what direction might Browning take Archewell in - and does this hint at the kind of output we can expect from Harry and Meghan? Browning is a fellow Brit, although he grew up all over the world. He’s a veteran film and television producer, who has also run various companies and started his own. He co-founded Wayfare Entertainment in 2008, and joined FilmNation Entertainment in 2014, relocating from New York to Los Angeles in the process.  Browning’s early projects included the TV series Masters of Horror and Fear Itself. He also executive produced, with James Cameron, the schlocky underwater cave action-thriller Sanctum. It’s safe to assume that the Sussexes aren’t about to produce a sequel. Of more interest in Browning’s recent body of work. That’s characterised by sensitive, distinctive yet commercial indie projects - such as  , featuring a Pakistani-American stand-up comic whose parents want him to enter into an arranged marriage. That 2017 film drew acclaim on its Sundance premiere and went on to gross $56 million worldwide on a budget of just $5 million, as well as picking up an Oscar nomination for best original screenplay. He also worked on the cerebral sci-fi movie   and the stirring drama   - for which Brie Larson won a best actress Oscar. Additionally, Browning has executive produced successful screen adaptation of several novels, including Julian Barnes’  , starring Jim Broadbent, Charlotte Rampling, Harriet Walter and Michelle Dockery, and Ian McEwen’s  , starring Emma Thompson and Stanley Tucci. Browning then reunited with Thompson for  , in which she played a talk show host guided by Mindy Kaley’s new recruit. He also helped bring   to the screen: Armando Ianucci’s imaginative take on Charles Dickens, featuring bold creative choices and diverse casting. That experience should stand Browning in good stead when it comes to understanding Harry’s British point of view, and how to liaise between that and what works in Hollywood. Similarly, he knows how to turn out programming that is engrossing for viewers, as well as tackling important issues - whether it’s the intersection of the law and faith in The Children Act, Orthodox Judaism and sexuality in  , cultural differences in The Big Sick, colonial oppression in  , or systematic misogyny in Promising Young Woman. Browning is savvy about the streaming market too. Speaking to Deadline last January at Sundance, he commented on FilmNation’s record £13 million US sale of content to Amazon in 2019, led by movies like Late Night, saying that he felt it was an environment where the films would “get their best chance to reach an enthusiastic audience.” Browning also explained why they’d backed Promising Young Woman, with its “playful provocative script. It pulls no punches. It knows what it’s trying to say and I think that’s what audiences want from filmmakers.” He added that they’d pulled in plenty of well-known actors because it only took a day’s commitment, since they were shooting in LA. Speaking about his approach to projects, Browning said that FilmNation looked at “the financial profile of a film, the sales profile of a film, the distribution life of a film, and we’re trying to make responsible business decisions because most important to all of us is not that this company is thriving now but that it’s still thriving in 10 years.” However, he balanced that with backing singular ideas. “The real distinction point of any creative company is knowing where and when to take risks. The process here is that it starts with one person who works here thinking something is absolutely exceptional and not shutting up about it and conveying that to other people who work here.” Browning characterised their projects as “a little left of centre or a little representative of what is about to come in a cultural conversation.” That certainly sounds like it fits with the Sussexes’ new   and professed desire - as per the Archewell website - to “drive systemic cultural change across all communities, one act of compassion at a time”, and to use their production company in “harnessing the power of storytelling to embrace our shared humanity, amplifying diverse and inspiring content.” But beyond shared sensibilities about “inspiring content”, what’s perhaps most important here is Browning’s track record in actually delivering slick, professional projects that connect with audiences and make money. Given the Sussexes’ inexperience in this area (as demonstrated by their debut podcast) and the “demands” of  , having a partner with practical skills and knowledge is what might lift this from vaguely well-meant vanity project to real industry force. After all, there’s only so many times you can play the   card, or pal around with  . At some point, Harry and Meghan will need to let their work do the talking.

While last week’s Line of Duty   saw many of its record 9.6 million viewers fixated on the show’s bewildering acronyms (in particular, the rude-sounding  ), talk of the   was of Jimmy Savile.  As anti-corruption unit AC-12 looked into the murder investigation of journalist Gail Vella, they watched videos of her past reporting - which played rather like a  , but with some queasy real-life policing chucked in.  In one clip, Vella (Andi Osho) covered the conviction of former chief superintendent  , an unmasked member of a VIP paedophile ring who we last saw in series three of the drama. Jed Mercurio courted controversy then by including a doctored image of Fairbank and another suspect, local politician Dale Roach, alongside the real-life sex offender Jimmy Savile. But Savile wasn’t actually name-checked in the show until last night. In her report, referencing the cover-ups perpetrated by figures like Fairbank, Vella said: “It’s now a matter of public record that Jimmy Savile cultivated relationships with senior police officers” - accompanied once again by that image of Savile with Fairbank and Roach, blurring reality and fiction. Vella continued: “Savile exploited those relationships to intimidate anyone attempting to investigate his offending. We now realise what Savile was getting out of those relationships with senior police officers. What remains unknown - and uninvestigated - is what those officers were getting out of their relationship with Savile.” The explicit references to Savile shocked many viewers, who shared their uneasiness on Twitter. One commented “A Savile storyline? Poor taste to put it politely”, while another said: “Bloody hell, Mr Mercurio is going a bit bloody close to the bone with this one.” However, former chief prosecutor Nazir Afzal also took to Twitter, pointing out that “Jimmy Savile has been involved in more criminal conspiracies than anyone I’ve ever dealt with - real & fictional. No surprise he turns up in #LineofDuty.” Previously,   between the police and Savile, saying: “The fact is that Savile bragged of his close relationships with officers.” The series three storyline strongly evoked Operation Yewtree, and a subsequent investigation into links between organised crime and corrupt officers, in series five, had the very similar name of Operation Pear Tree. So, is Mercurio attempting some amateur detective work via his drama, in the vein of Serial or Tiger King? Or is he just using   to spice up the series? If the latter, he’s treading on dangerous ethical ground. It’s also a far cry from the   of Line of Duty, with its deliberately vague geographical setting (an unnamed city in the Midlands), fictional forces like Central Police, and clearly invented characters. That distancing allowed viewers to delve into the world of modern policing, while still enjoying it as a TV drama. But series six is inching ever more into our world - with uncomfortable results. It wasn’t just Savile who made a startling appearance last night. The late Vella’s producer told AC-12 that she was doing her own podcast, to reveal truths that she couldn’t get on air, and that she was inspired by the podcast on Daniel Morgan. Again, this is a blatant true-crime reference. The cited podcast -  , presented by Peter Jukes and brother Alistair Morgan - delves into the murder of the private investigator in 1987. It alleges that Morgan had uncovered major corruption and drug trafficking within the Metropolitan Police, and that he was killed to stop him exposing it. Morgan’s murder officially remains unsolved. There’s also the inescapable parallels between Line of Duty’s Vella case and the killing of   - including the police questioning whether the perpetrator was an obsessive fan (the accused Barry George in real life; Terry Boyle in the drama), or whether this was a professional hit job. Mercurio’s series has always had a basis in actual policing. The writer consults retired and servicing officers on his scripts, and scans anonymous police blogs. That’s evident in the series’ assiduous use of  , regulations, paperwork, and painstaking interviews.  But this latest series is much blunter about dragging in real-world parallels, making it jarring for viewers. There is still a certain suspension of disbelief needed to make Line of Duty work, and that’s at odds with its fictional journalist actually commentating on Savile. Vella also referenced series one’s corruption case, involving a counter-terrorism squad raiding the wrong flat and shooting an innocent man, then lying to cover each other’s backs. AC-12’s Superintendent Hastings, played by  , is particularly outraged that the unit’s commanding officer - who led the cover-up - was then “made chief”. The plot line is obviously inspired by the murder of Jean Charles de Menezes, who was wrongly identified as a suicide bomber by the Met and gunned down at Stockwell Tube station in 2005; in the aftermath, officers initially lied about their actions. So, is this Mercurio criticising the appointment of Cressida Dick - who headed the operation - as Met chief? Dick has also, of course, been in the news recently after her force’s poor handling of the Sarah Everard vigil. An unrepentant Dick has expressed outrage at Mercurio’s portrayal of “the level of casual and extreme corruption” in the police. And while the series isn’t a documentary, and makes no such claims, it does have certain responsibilities as a popular primetime BBC programme. Can Mercurio really make allegations about actual crimes and police officers via his show?  It might be just about acceptable legally - even, some might argue, a public service - but it’s dubious dramatically. If we’re meant to be viewing Line of Duty with the sober earnestness applied to the Dando, Savile or de Menezes cases, that’s a very different proposition to enjoying a Sunday-night thriller with some basis in reality, but which takes plenty of creative license. In short: it sucks the fun out of it. Start treating the realm of Line of Duty as one bound by the rules of actual policing, and the whole thing collapses. Of course our AC-12 team would have been disbanded by now, given their many and various misdemeanours (not least sleeping with an unending string of suspects and witnesses). Nor should they be investigating the unit where their former colleague, Kate Fleming, works. That’s a job for AC-1-through-11, surely. And series three’s   is utterly absurd if you place it in a real-world context. Mercurio should also take care that he doesn’t put the spotlight on his own actions. A telling line in last night’s episode, in reference to Vella, was “female journalists get the worst of it.” Well, they do from Mercurio, who attacked a Guardian journalist on Twitter in 2019 for daring to criticise his show and, speaking to GQ earlier this month, doubled down by calling her a c___. Opening up Line of Duty to serious scrutiny is a Pandora’s box. Mercurio might well regret it - and so will his viewers.

Female performers will always be under more pressure to look good than their male counterparts, believes  . Reflecting on her career, she noted that women were constantly sexualised, and that even though that culture has shifted, we’re unlikely to ever have true equality. The Absolutely Fabulous actress commented on the industry while speaking to Libby Purves at last night’s Telegraph Subscriber event, A Night In With Joanna Lumley. “Women for a long, long time were the lovely ones, and you always had to look extremely beautiful if you were going to be an actress,” said Lumley. “If you’re a beauty queen, you understand that. But if you’re an actress, you’re playing a part. Why do you have to be beautiful?” In contrast, she noted, male performers “like Humphrey Bogart could have lined cheeks and furrowed brows. It’s always been unfair. And guess what: it’s always going to be unfair.  “I know people are always trying to reach for parity. I’ve a funny feeling it will never happen, because in the whole long time that human beings have been alive, women have always had to look good for men to like them, and men have always had to be ‘attractive’ for women to like them. ‘Attractive’ means they might have lots of money, or might be good at something, or might look as though they could provide. They didn’t have to be handsome necessarily.” Lumley also recalled being ordered to strip off for roles in the 1970s. “It was absolutely mandatory, and if you didn’t want to do it, they’d go ‘Are you an actress or not?’.” Since Lumley was coming from the modelling world, and hadn’t been to drama school, she felt she had to comply. But it wasn’t just her, she notes. “Everybody had to take their tops off. You just see it with Vanessa Redgrave, Glenda Jackson, Jacqueline Bisset… Everybody had to strip their tops off. That was completely par for the course.” She added: “I hated it. I’ve never met a single person who likes to get their clothes off. Or indeed people who like to do love scenes. Everybody was revolted by love scenes.” Lumley recounted another grim experience, while taking her announcement picture for playing Purdey in The New Avengers. “They put me in a flimsy, flimsy dress with flimsy high heels, and they said ‘We’d like you to stick a gun in your stocking top, Joanna’, and I said ‘But I’m wearing tights’.”  They refused to take her picture without stockings, so she had to borrow some from a stranger. “Everything was like that in those days,” she explained. “You just did it. I hate having to have done it. Which is why when I eventually was asked to do stage parts like Hedda Gabler and Madame Ranevskaya, it was sweet as a nut. I’m never asked to do those parts on television. I’m still either a bitch or glamorous.” The exception was Ab Fab, where she was allowed to play a grotesque alongside Jennifer Saunders. “The more ridiculous and revolting we looked, the more people loved them.” Lumley described Patsy as hunching over because “she’s had all her inside taken out and her bottom [was] gone. She hadn’t eaten since 1974.” Patsy’s hair evoked Ivanna Trump’s, she added, and her smirking laugh was based on Elvis. Lumley, who is married to conductor Stephen Barlow, and is a trustee of Grange Park Opera, also commented on how the emphasis on physical appearance has changed in the opera world.  “In the old days, the voice was everything, and people thought you should just go to the theatre, the opera house and be grateful for the sound,” she noted. “Then gradually it began to creep in that more and more directors, and maybe even the public, said ‘Hang on, if she’s playing this drop-dead gorgeous woman, maybe she should look a little bit better than that. Maybe she shouldn’t look like ten-ton Tessie.' I’ll probably be killed for even saying that.  “But the truth is maybe she   look a little bit more like the role. Because a lot of that overeating was part of it. It was a kind of myth that the way to have a beautiful voice was to be quite big and bosom-y and fat stomach-ed. That’s been disproved. Now you see the most gorgeous opera singers with ravishing voices looking great. And of course they’re much fitter and they’re much lither and they’re much more believable as actresses, as singing actresses, on stage.” In her own career, Lumley got an early acting break with a guest role on Coronation Street as a love interest for Ken Barlow. “I was written as just an interlude,” she explained. “His wife had just been killed by a hairdryer. The whole world was in shock: ‘What would handsome Ken do now?’. I was the schoolmaster's daughter. I shimmied into his life.” It was an exciting opportunity – and one she was eager to extend. But the producers were firm that it was just an eight-episode run. In fact, she was asked to reprise the role recently but wasn’t able to do it, so Stephanie Beacham joined the show instead. “I was jealous as hell of her,” admitted Lumley. But her great love is Shakespeare – which she’s never been asked to do professionally, she lamented. Her dream role is Rosalind in As You Like It. As for her other role as an activist, working with organisations like Kids for Kids in Dafur and the Gurkha Justice Campaign, might that tempt Lumley to go into politics fulltime? Certainly not. “I had a glimpse of it during the gurkha campaign. I had a look into the corridors of power, and it doesn’t appeal to me because it’s too slow. I don’t want it to go into some committee in a month’s time and then people say ‘We’ll look at it more closely.’ I can’t bear all that. I want it to be done now. So I wouldn’t mind being a benevolent dictator, but I don’t want to be in Parliament.”
